17656.text: §¶The vision that Isaiah the son of Aʹmoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uz·ziʹah, Joʹtham, Aʹhaz, and Hez·e·kiʹah, kings of Judah:

17657.text: ¶ Hear, O heavens, and pay attention, O earth,/_For Jehovah has spoken:/_“Sons I have brought up and raised,/_But they have revolted against me.

17658.text: ¶ A bull well knows its buyer,/_And a donkey the manger of its owner;/_But Israel does not know me,/_My own people do not behave with understanding.”

17659.text: ¶ Woe to the sinful nation,/_The people weighed down with error,/_A brood of wicked men, corrupt children!/_They have abandoned Jehovah;/_They have treated the Holy One of Israel with disrespect;/_They have turned their backs on him.

17660.text: ¶ Where will you be struck next as you add to your rebellion?/_The whole head is sick,/_And the whole heart is diseased.

17661.text: ¶ From the sole of the foot to the head, nothing is healthy./_There are wounds and bruises and open sores/_—They have not been treated or bound up or softened with oil.

17662.text: ¶ Your land is desolate./_Your cities are burned with fire./_Foreigners devour your land right in front of you./_It is like a wasteland overthrown by foreigners.

17663.text: ¶ The daughter of Zion has been left like a shelter in a vineyard,/_Like a hut in a cucumber field,/_Like a city under siege.

17664.text: ¶ Unless Jehovah of armies had left us a few survivors,/_We should have become just like Sodʹom,/_And we should have resembled Go·morʹrah.

17665.text: §¶Hear the word of Jehovah, you dictators of Sodʹom./_Pay attention to the law of our God, you people of Go·morʹrah.

17666.text: ¶“Of what benefit to me are your many sacrifices?” says Jehovah./_“I have had enough of your burnt offerings of rams and the fat of well‑fed animals,/_And I have no delight in the blood of young bulls and lambs and goats.

17667.text: ¶When you come to appear before me,/_Who has required this from you,/_This trampling of my courtyards?

17668.text: ¶Stop bringing in any more worthless grain offerings./_Your incense is detestable to me./_New moons, sabbaths, the calling of conventions/_—I cannot put up with the use of magical power along with your solemn assembly.

17669.text: ¶I have hated your new moons and your festivals./_They have become a burden to me;/_I am tired of bearing them.

17670.text: ¶And when you spread out your palms,/_I hide my eyes from you./_Although you offer many prayers,/_I am not listening;/_Your hands are filled with blood.

17671.text: ¶Wash yourselves, make yourselves clean;/_Remove your evil deeds from my sight;/_Stop doing bad.

17672.text: ¶Learn to do good, seek justice,/_Correct the oppressor,/_Defend the rights of the fatherless child,/_And plead the cause of the widow.”

17673.text: §¶“Come, now, and let us set matters straight between us,” says Jehovah./_“Though your sins are like scarlet,/_They will be made as white as snow;/_Though they are as red as crimson cloth,/_They will become like wool.

17674.text: ¶If you show willingness and listen,/_You will eat the good things of the land.

17675.text: ¶But if you refuse and rebel,/_You will be devoured by the sword,/_For the mouth of Jehovah has spoken it.”

17676.text: §¶How the faithful city has become a prostitute!/_She was full of justice;/_Righteousness used to lodge in her,/_But now murderers.

17677.text: ¶Your silver has become dross,/_And your beer is diluted with water.

17678.text: ¶Your princes are stubborn and partners with thieves./_Every one of them loves a bribe and chases after gifts./_They do not grant justice to the fatherless,/_And the legal case of the widow never reaches them.

17679.text: ¶Therefore the true Lord, Jehovah of armies,/_The Powerful One of Israel, declares:/_“Ah! I will rid myself of my adversaries,/_And I will take revenge on my enemies.

17680.text: ¶I will turn my hand against you,/_I will smelt away your dross as with lye,/_And I will remove all your impurities.

17681.text: ¶I will restore your judges as in the beginning/_And your advisers as at the start./_After this you will be called City of Righteousness, Faithful Town.

17682.text: ¶With justice Zion will be redeemed,/_And her people who return, with righteousness.

17683.text: ¶The rebels and the sinners will be broken together,/_And those leaving Jehovah will come to their finish.

17684.text: ¶For they will be ashamed of the mighty trees that you desired,/_And you will be disgraced because of the gardens that you chose.

17685.text: ¶For you will become like a big tree with withering leaves,/_And like a garden without water.

17686.text: ¶The strong man will become tow,/_And his work a spark;/_Both of them will go up in flames together,/_With no one to extinguish them.”

17687.text: §¶This is what Isaiah the son of Aʹmoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:

17688.text: ¶ In the final part of the days,/_The mountain of the house of Jehovah/_Will become firmly established above the top of the mountains,/_And it will be raised up above the hills,/_And to it all the nations will stream.

17689.text: ¶ And many peoples will go and say:/_“Come, let us go up to the mountain of Jehovah,/_To the house of the God of Jacob./_He will instruct us about his ways,/_And we will walk in his paths.”/_For law will go out of Zion,/_And the word of Jehovah out of Jerusalem.

17690.text: ¶ He will render judgment among the nations/_And set matters straight respecting many peoples./_They will beat their swords into plowshares/_And their spears into pruning shears./_Nation will not lift up sword against nation,/_Nor will they learn war anymore.

17691.text: ¶ O house of Jacob, come,/_Let us walk in the light of Jehovah.

17692.text: §¶ For you have forsaken your people, the house of Jacob,/_Because they have become full of things from the East;/_They practice magic like the Phi·lisʹtines,/_And they abound with the children of foreigners.

17693.text: ¶ Their land is filled with silver and gold,/_And there is no limit to their treasures./_Their land is filled with horses,/_And there is no limit to their chariots.

17694.text: ¶ Their land is filled with worthless gods./_They bow down to the work of their own hands,/_To what their own fingers have made.

17695.text: ¶ So man bows down, he becomes low,/_And you cannot possibly pardon them.

17696.text: ¶Enter into the rock and hide yourself in the dust/_Because of the terrifying presence of Jehovah/_And his majestic splendor.

17697.text: ¶The haughty eyes of man will be brought low,/_And the arrogance of men will bow down./_Jehovah alone will be exalted in that day.

17698.text: ¶For it is the day belonging to Jehovah of armies./_It is coming upon everyone who is haughty and lofty,/_Upon everyone, whether exalted or lowly,

17699.text: ¶Upon all the cedars of Lebʹa·non that are lofty and exalted/_And upon all the oaks of Baʹshan,

17700.text: ¶Upon all the lofty mountains/_And upon all the high hills,

17701.text: ¶Upon every high tower and every fortified wall,

17702.text: ¶Upon all the ships of Tarʹshish/_And upon all desirable boats.

17703.text: ¶Man’s haughtiness will be brought down,/_And the arrogance of men will bow low./_Jehovah alone will be exalted in that day.

17705.text: ¶And people will enter into the caves of the rocks/_And into the holes in the ground,/_Because of the terrifying presence of Jehovah/_And his majestic splendor,/_When he arises to make the earth tremble in terror.

17706.text: ¶In that day men will take their worthless gods of silver and of gold/_That they had made for themselves to bow down to/_And throw them away to the shrewmice and to the bats,

17707.text: ¶In order to enter into the holes in the rocks/_And into the clefts of the crags,/_Because of the terrifying presence of Jehovah/_And his majestic splendor,/_When he arises to make the earth tremble in terror.

17708.text: ¶For your own sakes, quit trusting in mere man,/_Who is only the breath in his nostrils./_Why should he be taken into account?

17709.text: §¶For look! the true Lord, Jehovah of armies,/_Is removing from Jerusalem and Judah every kind of support and supply,/_All support of bread and water,

17710.text: ¶ Mighty man and warrior,/_Judge and prophet, diviner and elder,

17711.text: ¶ Chief of 50, dignitary, and adviser,/_The expert magician and the skilled charmer.

17712.text: ¶ I will make boys their princes,/_And the unstable will rule over them.

17713.text: ¶ The people will oppress one another,/_Each one his fellow man./_The boy will assault the old man,/_And the lightly esteemed one will defy the respected one.

17714.text: ¶ Each one will take hold of his brother in his father’s house and say:/_“You have a cloak—you be our commander./_Take charge of this overthrown pile of ruins.”

17715.text: ¶ But he will protest in that day:/_“I will not be your wound dresser;/_I have no food or clothing in my house./_Do not make me commander over the people.”

17716.text: ¶ For Jerusalem has stumbled,/_And Judah has fallen,/_Because in word and deed they are against Jehovah;/_They behave defiantly in his glorious presence.

17717.text: ¶ The expression of their faces testifies against them,/_And they proclaim their sin like Sodʹom;/_They do not try to hide it./_Woe to them, for they are bringing disaster on themselves!

17718.text: ¶Tell the righteous that it will go well for them;/_They will be rewarded for what they do.

17719.text: ¶Woe to the wicked one!/_Disaster will befall him,/_For what his hands have done will be done to him!

17720.text: ¶As for my people, their taskmasters are abusive,/_And women rule over them./_My people, your leaders are causing you to wander,/_And they confuse the direction of your paths.

17721.text: ¶Jehovah is taking his position to accuse;/_He is standing up to pass sentence on peoples.

17722.text: ¶Jehovah will enter into judgment with the elders and princes of his people./_“You have burned down the vineyard,/_And what you have stolen from the poor is in your houses.

17723.text: ¶How dare you crush my people/_And grind the faces of the poor in the dirt?” declares the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies.

17724.text: §¶Jehovah says: “Because the daughters of Zion are haughty,/_Walking with their heads high,/_Flirting with their eyes, skipping along,/_Making a tinkling sound with their anklets,

17725.text: ¶Jehovah will also strike the head of the daughters of Zion with scabs,/_And Jehovah will make their forehead bare.

17726.text: ¶In that day Jehovah will take away the beauty of their bangles,/_The headbands and the crescent‑shaped ornaments,

17727.text: ¶The earrings, the bracelets, and the veils,

17728.text: ¶The headdresses, the ankle chains, and the breastbands,/_The perfume receptacles and the charms,

17729.text: ¶The finger rings and the nose rings,

17730.text: ¶The ceremonial robes, the overtunics, the cloaks, and the purses,

17731.text: ¶The hand mirrors and the linen garments,/_The turbans and the veils.

17732.text: ¶Instead of balsam oil, there will be a rotten smell;/_Instead of a belt, a rope;/_Instead of a beautiful hairstyle, baldness;/_Instead of a rich garment, a garment of sackcloth;/_And a brand mark instead of beauty.

17733.text: ¶By the sword your men will fall,/_And your mighty men in battle.

17734.text: ¶Her entrances will mourn and grieve,/_And she will sit on the ground desolate.”

17735.text: §¶And seven women will grab hold of one man in that day, saying:¶▼“We will eat our own bread/_And wear our own clothing;/_Only let us be called by your name/_To take away our disgrace.”

17736.text: §¶In that day what Jehovah makes sprout will be splendid and glorious, and the fruitage of the land will be the pride and beauty of the survivors of Israel.

17737.text: Whoever remains in Zion and is left over in Jerusalem will be called holy, all of those in Jerusalem written down for life.

17738.text: ¶When Jehovah washes away the filth of the daughters of Zion and rinses away the bloodshed of Jerusalem from her midst by the spirit of judgment and by a spirit of burning,

17739.text: Jehovah will also create over the whole site of Mount Zion and over the place of her conventions a cloud and smoke by day and a bright flaming fire by night; for over all the glory there will be a shelter.

17740.text: And there will be a booth for shade by day from the heat, and for refuge and protection from storms and the rain.

17741.text: §¶Let me sing, please, to my beloved/_A song about my loved one and his vineyard./_My beloved had a vineyard on a fruitful hillside.

17742.text: ¶ He dug it up and rid it of stones./_He planted it with a choice red vine,/_Built a tower in the middle of it,/_And hewed out a winepress in it./_Then he kept hoping for it to produce grapes,/_But it produced only wild grapes.

17743.text: ¶ “And now, you inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah,/_Please judge between me and my vineyard.

17744.text: ¶ What more could I have done for my vineyard/_That I have not already done?/_Why, when I hoped for grapes,/_Did it produce only wild grapes?

17745.text: ¶ Now, please, let me tell you/_What I will do to my vineyard:/_I will remove its hedge,/_And it will be burned down./_I will break down its stone wall,/_And it will be trampled on.

17746.text: ¶ I will make it a wasteland;/_It will not be pruned or hoed./_It will be overgrown with thornbushes and weeds,/_And I will command the clouds not to send any rain on it.

17747.text: ¶ For the vineyard of Jehovah of armies is the house of Israel;/_The men of Judah are the plantation he was fond of./_He kept hoping for justice,/_But look! there was injustice;/_For righteousness,/_But look! a cry of distress.”

17748.text: §¶ Woe to those who join one house to another house/_And who annex one field to another field/_Until there is no more room/_And you live by yourselves on the land!

17749.text: ¶ Jehovah of armies has sworn in my ears/_That many houses, though great and beautiful,/_Will become an object of horror,/_Without an inhabitant.

17750.text: ¶For ten acres of vineyard will produce but one bath measure,/_And a hoʹmer measure of seed will produce only an eʹphah.

17751.text: ¶Woe to those who get up early in the morning to drink alcohol,/_Who linger late into the evening darkness until wine inflames them!

17752.text: ¶They have harp and stringed instrument,/_Tambourine, flute, and wine at their feasts;/_But they do not consider the activity of Jehovah,/_And they do not see the work of his hands.

17753.text: ¶So my people will go into exile/_For lack of knowledge;/_Their glorious men will go hungry,/_And all their people will be parched with thirst.

17754.text: ¶So the Grave has enlarged itself/_And has opened its mouth wide without limit;/_And her splendor, her noisy multitudes, and her revelers/_Will certainly go down into it.

17755.text: ¶And man will bow down,/_Man will be brought low,/_And the eyes of the haughty will be brought low.

17756.text: ¶Jehovah of armies will be exalted by his judgment;/_The true God, the Holy One, will sanctify himself through righteousness.

17757.text: ¶And the lambs will graze as in their pasture;/_Foreign residents will feed on the desolate places of well‑fed animals.

17758.text: ¶Woe to those who drag along their guilt with ropes of deception/_And their sin with wagon cords;

17759.text: ¶Those who say: “Let Him speed up his work;/_Let it come quickly that we may see it./_Let the purpose of the Holy One of Israel take place/_That we may know it!”

17760.text: ¶Woe to those who say that good is bad and bad is good,/_Those who substitute darkness for light and light for darkness,/_Those who put bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter!

17761.text: ¶Woe to those wise in their own eyes/_And discreet in their own sight!

17762.text: ¶Woe to those who are mighty in drinking wine/_And to the men who are masters at mixing alcoholic drinks,

17763.text: ¶Those who acquit the wicked for a bribe/_And who deny justice to the righteous!

17764.text: ¶Therefore, just as the tongue of fire consumes the stubble/_And dry grass shrivels in the flames,/_Their very roots will rot,/_And their blossoms will scatter like powder,/_Because they rejected the law of Jehovah of armies/_And disrespected the word of the Holy One of Israel.

17765.text: §¶That is why the anger of Jehovah burns against his people,/_And he will stretch out his hand against them and strike them./_The mountains will quake,/_And their corpses will be like refuse in the streets./_In view of all this, his anger has not turned back,/_But his hand is still stretched out to strike.

17766.text: ¶He has raised up a signal to a distant nation;/_He has whistled for them to come from the ends of the earth;/_And look! they are coming very swiftly.

17767.text: ¶None among them are tired or stumbling./_No one is drowsy or sleeps./_The belt around their waist is not loosened,/_Nor are their sandal laces broken.

17768.text: ¶All their arrows are sharp,/_And all their bows are bent./_The hooves of their horses are like flint,/_And their wheels like a storm wind.

17769.text: ¶Their roaring is like that of a lion;/_They roar like young lions./_They will growl and seize the prey/_And carry it off with no one to rescue it.

17770.text: ¶In that day they will growl over it/_Like the growling of the sea./_Anyone who gazes at the land will see distressing darkness;/_Even the light has grown dark because of the clouds.

17771.text: §¶In the year that King Uz·ziʹah died, I saw Jehovah sitting on a lofty and elevated throne, and the skirts of his robe filled the temple.

17772.text: Seraphs were standing above him; each had six wings. Each covered his face with two and covered his feet with two, and each of them would fly about with two.

17773.text: ¶ And one called to the other:/_“Holy, holy, holy is Jehovah of armies./_The whole earth is filled with his glory.”

17774.text: ¶And the pivots of the thresholds quivered at the sound of the shouting, and the house was filled with smoke.

17775.text: §¶ Then I said: “Woe to me!/_I am as good as dead,/_For I am a man of unclean lips,/_And I live among a people of unclean lips;/_For my eyes have seen the King, Jehovah of armies himself!”

17776.text: ¶At that, one of the seraphs flew to me, and in his hand was a glowing coal that he had taken with tongs from the altar.

17777.text: He touched my mouth and said:¶▼“Look! This has touched your lips./_Your guilt is removed,/_And your sin is atoned for.”

17778.text: §¶Then I heard the voice of Jehovah saying: “Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?” And I said: “Here I am! Send me!”

17779.text: ¶ And he replied, “Go, and say to this people:/_‘You will hear again and again,/_But you will not understand;/_You will see again and again,/_But you will not get any knowledge.’

17780.text: ¶Make the heart of this people unreceptive,/_Make their ears unresponsive,/_And paste their eyes together,/_So that they may not see with their eyes/_And hear with their ears,/_So that their heart may not understand/_And they may not turn back and be healed.”

17781.text: §¶At this I said: “How long, O Jehovah?” Then he said:¶▼“Until the cities crash in ruins without an inhabitant/_And the houses are without people/_And the land is ruined and desolate;

17782.text: ¶Until Jehovah removes men far away/_And the deserted condition of the land becomes very extensive.

17783.text: ¶“But there will still be a tenth in it, and it will again be burned, like a big tree and like an oak, which after they are cut down leave a stump; a holy seed will be its stump.”

17784.text: §¶Now in the days of Aʹhaz son of Joʹtham son of Uz·ziʹah, the king of Judah, King Reʹzin of Syria and Peʹkah son of Rem·a·liʹah, the king of Israel, came up to wage war against Jerusalem, but he could not capture it.

17785.text: A report was made to the house of David: “Syria has joined forces with Eʹphra·im.”¶And the heart of Aʹhaz and the heart of his people began to tremble, like the trees of the forest shaking in the wind.

17786.text: ¶Jehovah then said to Isaiah: “Go out, please, to meet Aʹhaz, you and your son Sheʹar‑jaʹshub, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool by the highway of the laundryman’s field.

17787.text: You must say to him, ‘Take care to stay calm. Do not be afraid, and do not lose heart because of these two stumps of smoldering logs, because of the hot anger of Reʹzin and Syria and the son of Rem·a·liʹah.

17788.text: For Syria with Eʹphra·im and the son of Rem·a·liʹah have plotted harm against you, saying:

17789.text: “Let us go up against Judah and tear it apart and conquer it for ourselves, and let us appoint the son of Tabʹe·el as its king.”

17790.text: ¶ “‘This is what the Sovereign Lord Jehovah says:/_“It will not succeed,/_Nor will it take place.

17791.text: ¶ For the head of Syria is Damascus,/_And the head of Damascus is Reʹzin./_Within just 65 years/_Eʹphra·im will be completely shattered and cease to be a people.

17792.text: ¶ The head of Eʹphra·im is Sa·marʹi·a,/_And the head of Sa·marʹi·a is the son of Rem·a·liʹah./_Unless you have firm faith,/_You will not be firmly established.”’”

17794.text: “Ask for a sign from Jehovah your God; it may be as deep as the Grave or as high as the sky.”

17795.text: But Aʹhaz said: “I will not ask, nor will I put Jehovah to the test.”

17796.text: ¶Isaiah then said: “Listen, please, O house of David. Is it not enough that you try the patience of men? Must you also try the patience of God?

17797.text: Therefore, Jehovah himself will give you a sign: Look! The young woman will become pregnant and will give birth to a son, and she will name him Im·manʹu·el.

17798.text: He will eat butter and honey by the time that he knows how to reject the bad and choose the good.

17799.text: For before the boy knows how to reject the bad and choose the good, the land of the two kings whom you dread will be completely abandoned.

17800.text: Jehovah will bring against you and against your people and against the house of your father a time such as has not come since the day Eʹphra·im broke away from Judah, for He will bring the king of As·syrʹi·a.

17801.text: §¶“In that day Jehovah will whistle for the flies from the distant streams of the Nile of Egypt and for the bees in the land of As·syrʹi·a,

17802.text: and they will all come and settle down on the steep valleys, on the rocky clefts, on all the thornbushes, and on all the watering places.

17803.text: ¶“In that day by means of a hired razor from the region of the River, by means of the king of As·syrʹi·a, Jehovah will shave the head and the hair of the legs, and it will sweep away the beard as well.

17804.text: ¶“In that day a man will keep alive a young cow of the herd and two sheep.

17805.text: And because of the abundance of milk, he will eat butter, for everyone remaining in the land will eat butter and honey.

17806.text: ¶“In that day wherever there used to be 1,000 vines worth 1,000 pieces of silver, there will be only thornbushes and weeds.

17807.text: Men will go there with bow and arrow, because all the land will become thornbushes and weeds.

17808.text: And all the mountains that used to be cleared with a hoe, you will not go near for fear of thornbushes and weeds; they will become a grazing place for bulls and a trampling ground of sheep.”

17809.text: §¶Jehovah said to me: “Take a large tablet and write on it with an ordinary stylus, ‘Maʹher‑shalʹal‑hash‑baz.’

17810.text: And let me have it confirmed in writing by faithful witnesses, U·riʹah the priest and Zech·a·riʹah the son of Je·ber·e·chiʹah.”

17811.text: ¶Then I had relations with the prophetess, and she became pregnant and in time gave birth to a son. Jehovah then said to me: “Name him Maʹher‑shalʹal‑hash‑baz,

17812.text: for before the boy knows how to call out, ‘My father!’ and ‘My mother!’ the resources of Damascus and the spoil of Sa·marʹi·a will be carried away before the king of As·syrʹi·a.”

17814.text: ¶ “Because this people has rejected the gently flowing waters of the Shi·loʹah/_And they rejoice over Reʹzin and the son of Rem·a·liʹah,

17815.text: ¶ Therefore look! Jehovah will bring against them/_The mighty and vast waters of the River,/_The king of As·syrʹi·a and all his glory./_He will come up over all his streambeds/_And overflow all his banks

17816.text: ¶ And sweep through Judah./_He will flood and pass through, reaching to the neck;/_His outspread wings will fill the breadth of your land,/_O Im·manʹu·el!”

17817.text: §¶ Cause harm, you peoples, but you will be shattered to pieces./_Listen, all you from distant parts of the earth!/_Prepare for battle, but you will be shattered to pieces!/_Prepare for battle, but you will be shattered to pieces!

17818.text: ¶Devise a plan, but it will be thwarted!/_Say what you like, but it will not succeed,/_For God is with us!

17819.text: ¶With his strong hand on me, this is what Jehovah said to me to warn me away from following the course of this people:

17820.text: ¶“You should not call a conspiracy what this people calls a conspiracy!/_Do not fear what they fear;/_Do not tremble at it.

17821.text: ¶Jehovah of armies—he is the One you should regard as holy,/_He is the One you should fear,/_And he is the One who should cause you to tremble.”

17822.text: ¶He will become as a sanctuary,/_But as a stone to strike against/_And as a rock to stumble over/_To both houses of Israel,/_As a trap and a snare/_To the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

17823.text: ¶Many of them will stumble and fall and be broken;/_They will be ensnared and caught.

17824.text: ¶Wrap up the written confirmation;/_Seal up the law among my disciples!

17825.text: ¶I will keep in expectation of Jehovah, who is hiding his face from the house of Jacob, and I will hope in him.

17826.text: §¶Look! I and the children whom Jehovah has given me are as signs and as miracles in Israel from Jehovah of armies, who resides on Mount Zion.

17827.text: §¶And if they say to you: “Inquire of the spirit mediums or of the fortune‑tellers who chirp and mutter,” is it not of their God that a people should inquire? Should they inquire of the dead in behalf of the living?

17828.text: Instead, they should inquire of the law and of the written confirmation!¶When they do not speak according to this word, they have no light.

17829.text: And each one will pass through the land afflicted and hungry; and because he is hungry and indignant, he will curse his king and his God as he looks upward.

17830.text: Then he will look to the earth and see only distress and darkness, obscurity and hard times, gloom and no brightness.

17831.text: §¶However, the gloom will not be as when the land had distress, as in former times when the land of Zebʹu·lun and the land of Naphʹta·li were treated with contempt. But at a later time He will cause it to be honored—the way by the sea, in the region of the Jordan, Galʹi·lee of the nations.

17832.text: ¶ The people who were walking in the darkness/_Have seen a great light./_As for those dwelling in the land of deep shadow,/_Light has shone on them.

17833.text: ¶ You have made the nation populous;/_You have made its rejoicing great./_They rejoice before you/_As people rejoice in the harvesttime,/_As those who joyfully divide up the spoil.

17834.text: ¶ For you have shattered to pieces the yoke of their load,/_The rod on their shoulders, the staff of the taskmaster,/_As in the day of Midʹi·an.

17835.text: ¶ Every boot that shakes the earth as it marches/_And every garment soaked in blood/_Will become fuel for the fire.

17836.text: ¶ For a child has been born to us,/_A son has been given to us;/_And the rulership will rest on his shoulder./_His name will be called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Eternal Father, Prince of Peace.

17837.text: ¶ To the increase of his rulership/_And to peace, there will be no end,/_On the throne of David and on his kingdom/_In order to establish it firmly and to sustain it/_Through justice and righteousness,/_From now on and forever./_The zeal of Jehovah of armies will do this.

17838.text: §¶ Jehovah sent a word against Jacob,/_And it has come against Israel.

17839.text: ¶ And all the people will know it/_—Eʹphra·im and the inhabitants of Sa·marʹi·a—/_Who say in their haughtiness and in their insolence of heart:

17840.text: ¶“Bricks have fallen,/_But we will build with hewn stone./_Sycamore trees have been cut down,/_But we will replace them with cedars.”

17841.text: ¶Jehovah will raise up Reʹzin’s adversaries against him/_And will stir his enemies to action,

17842.text: ¶Syria from the east and the Phi·lisʹtines from the west,/_They will devour Israel with open mouths./_In view of all this, his anger has not turned back,/_But his hand is still stretched out to strike.

17843.text: ¶For the people have not returned to the One who strikes them;/_They have not sought Jehovah of armies.

17844.text: ¶Jehovah will cut off from Israel/_Head and tail, shoot and rush, in one day.

17845.text: ¶The elder and highly respected one is the head,/_And the prophet giving false instruction is the tail.

17846.text: ¶Those leading this people are causing them to wander,/_And those who are being led are confused.

17847.text: ¶That is why Jehovah will not rejoice over their young men,/_And he will have no mercy on their fatherless children and their widows/_Because all of them are apostates and evildoers/_And every mouth is speaking senselessness./_In view of all this, his anger has not turned back,/_But his hand is still stretched out to strike.

17848.text: ¶For wickedness burns like a fire,/_Consuming thornbushes and weeds./_It will set fire to the thickets of the forest,/_And they will go up in clouds of smoke.

17849.text: ¶In the fury of Jehovah of armies/_The land has been set on fire,/_And the people will become fuel for the fire./_No one will spare even his brother.

17850.text: ¶One will cut down on the right/_But still be hungry;/_And one will eat on the left/_But will not be satisfied./_Each will devour the flesh of his own arm,

17851.text: ¶Ma·nasʹseh will devour Eʹphra·im,/_And Eʹphra·im Ma·nasʹseh./_Together they will be against Judah./_In view of all this, his anger has not turned back,/_But his hand is still stretched out to strike.

17852.text: §¶Woe to those who enact harmful regulations,/_Who constantly draft oppressive decrees,

17853.text: ¶ To deny the legal claim of the poor,/_To deprive the lowly among my people of justice,/_Making widows their spoil/_And fatherless children their plunder!

17854.text: ¶ What will you do on the day of reckoning,/_When destruction comes from afar?/_To whom will you flee for assistance,/_And where will you leave your wealth?

17855.text: ¶ Nothing remains except to crouch among the prisoners/_Or to fall among the slain./_In view of all this, his anger has not turned back,/_But his hand is still stretched out to strike.

17856.text: §¶ “Aha! the As·syrʹi·an,/_The rod to express my anger/_And the staff in their hand for my denunciation!

17857.text: ¶ I will send him against an apostate nation,/_Against the people who infuriated me;/_I will command him to take much spoil and much plunder/_And to trample them like mud in the streets.

17858.text: ¶ But he will not be inclined this way/_And his heart will not scheme this way;/_For it is in his heart to annihilate,/_To cut off many nations, not a few.

17859.text: ¶ For he says,/_‘Are not my princes all kings?

17860.text: ¶ Is not Calʹno just like Carʹche·mish?/_Is not Haʹmath like Arʹpad?/_Is not Sa·marʹi·a like Damascus?

17861.text: ¶My hand has seized the kingdoms of the worthless gods,/_Whose graven images were more than those of Jerusalem and Sa·marʹi·a!

17862.text: ¶Will I not also do to Jerusalem and her idols/_Just as I have done to Sa·marʹi·a and to her worthless gods?’

17863.text: §¶“When Jehovah finishes all his work on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, He will punish the king of As·syrʹi·a for his insolent heart and his proud, arrogant gaze.

17864.text: For he says,¶▼‘I will do this by the strength of my hand/_And with my wisdom, for I am wise./_I will remove the boundaries of peoples/_And pillage their treasures,/_And I will subdue the inhabitants like a mighty one.

17865.text: ¶Like a man reaching into a nest,/_My hand will seize the resources of the peoples;/_And like one gathering abandoned eggs,/_I will gather the whole earth!/_No one will flutter his wings or open his mouth or chirp.’”

17866.text: ¶Will the ax exalt itself over the one who chops with it?/_Will the saw exalt itself over the one who saws with it?/_Could a staff wave the one who lifts it?/_Or could a rod lift up the one who is not made of wood?

17867.text: ¶Therefore the true Lord, Jehovah of armies,/_Will inflict emaciation on his fat ones,/_And beneath his glory he will kindle a blazing fire.

17868.text: ¶Israel’s Light will become a fire,/_And his Holy One a flame;/_It will blaze up and consume his weeds and his thornbushes in one day.

17869.text: ¶He will utterly do away with the glory of his forest and his orchard;/_It will be as when a sick man wastes away.

17870.text: ¶The rest of the trees of his forest/_Will be so few that a boy could list them.

17871.text: §¶In that day those remaining of Israel/_And the survivors of the house of Jacob/_Will no longer support themselves on the one who struck them;/_But they will support themselves on Jehovah,/_The Holy One of Israel, with faithfulness.

17872.text: ¶Only a remnant will return,/_The remnant of Jacob, to the Mighty God.

17873.text: ¶For though your people, O Israel,/_Are as the grains of sand of the sea,/_Only a remnant of them will return./_An extermination has been decided on,/_And justice will engulf them.

17874.text: ¶Yes, the extermination decided on by the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies,/_Will be carried out in the entire land.

17875.text: ¶Therefore this is what the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies, says: “Do not be afraid, my people who are dwelling in Zion, because of the As·syrʹi·an, who used to strike you with the rod and to lift up his staff against you as Egypt did.

17876.text: For in a very little while the denunciation will come to an end; my anger will be directed to their destruction.

17877.text: Jehovah of armies will brandish a whip against him, as when he defeated Midʹi·an by the rock Oʹreb. And his staff will be over the sea, and he will raise it as he did with Egypt.

17878.text: ¶In that day his load will depart from on your shoulder,/_And his yoke from on your neck,/_And the yoke will be broken because of the oil.”

17879.text: §¶He has come to Aiʹath;/_He has passed through Migʹron;/_At Michʹmash he deposits his baggage.

17880.text: ¶They have passed over the ford;/_They spend the night at Geʹba;/_Raʹmah trembles, Gibʹe·ah of Saul has fled.

17881.text: ¶Cry out and scream, O daughter of Galʹlim!/_Pay attention, O Laʹi·shah!/_O poor Anʹa·thoth!

17882.text: ¶Mad·meʹnah has run away./_The inhabitants of Geʹbim have sought shelter.

17883.text: ¶This very day he will halt in Nob./_He shakes his fist at the mountain of the daughter of Zion,/_The hill of Jerusalem.

17884.text: ¶Look! The true Lord, Jehovah of armies,/_Is chopping off branches with a terrible crash;/_The tallest trees are being cut down,/_And the lofty are brought low.

17885.text: ¶He strikes down the thickets of the forest with an iron tool,/_And Lebʹa·non will fall by a mighty one.

17886.text: §¶A twig will grow out of the stump of Jesʹse,/_And a sprout from his roots will bear fruit.

17887.text: ¶ And the spirit of Jehovah will settle upon him,/_The spirit of wisdom and of understanding,/_The spirit of counsel and of mightiness,/_The spirit of knowledge and of the fear of Jehovah.

17888.text: ¶ And he will find delight in the fear of Jehovah./_He will not judge by what appears to his eyes,/_Nor reprove simply according to what his ears hear.

17889.text: ¶ He will judge the lowly with fairness,/_And with uprightness he will give reproof in behalf of the meek ones of the earth./_He will strike the earth with the rod of his mouth/_And put the wicked to death with the breath of his lips.

17890.text: ¶ Righteousness will be the belt around his waist,/_And faithfulness the belt of his hips.

17891.text: ¶ The wolf will reside for a while with the lamb,/_And with the young goat the leopard will lie down,/_And the calf and the lion and the fattened animal will all be together;/_And a little boy will lead them.

17892.text: ¶ The cow and the bear will feed together,/_And their young will lie down together./_The lion will eat straw like the bull.

17893.text: ¶ The nursing child will play over the lair of a cobra,/_And a weaned child will put his hand over the den of a poisonous snake.

17894.text: ¶ They will not cause any harm/_Or any ruin in all my holy mountain,/_Because the earth will certainly be filled with the knowledge of Jehovah/_As the waters cover the sea.

17895.text: ¶In that day the root of Jesʹse will stand up as a signal for the peoples./_To him the nations will turn for guidance,/_And his resting‑place will become glorious.

17896.text: §¶In that day Jehovah will again offer his hand, a second time, to reclaim the remnant of his people who are left from As·syrʹi·a, from Egypt, from Pathʹros, from Cush, from Eʹlam, from Shiʹnar, from Haʹmath, and from the islands of the sea.

17897.text: He will raise up a signal for the nations and gather the dispersed ones of Israel, and he will gather together the scattered ones of Judah from the four corners of the earth.

17898.text: ¶The jealousy of Eʹphra·im will be gone,/_And those who show hostility to Judah will be done away with./_Eʹphra·im will not be jealous of Judah,/_Nor will Judah show hostility toward Eʹphra·im.

17899.text: ¶And they will swoop down on the slopes of the Phi·lisʹtines to the west;/_Together they will plunder the people of the East./_They will thrust out their hand against Eʹdom and Moʹab,/_And the Amʹmon·ites will become their subjects.

17900.text: ¶Jehovah will divide the gulf of the Egyptian sea/_And wave his hand over the River./_With his scorching breath he will strike it in its seven torrents,/_And he will cause people to walk across in their sandals.

17901.text: ¶And there will be a highway out of As·syrʹi·a for the remnant of his people who are left,/_As there was for Israel in the day he came out of the land of Egypt.

17902.text: §¶In that day you will certainly say:¶▼“I thank you, O Jehovah,/_For although you were angry with me,/_Your anger gradually subsided, and you comforted me.

17903.text: ¶ Look! God is my salvation./_I will trust and feel no dread;/_For Jah Jehovah is my strength and my might,/_And he has become my salvation.”

17904.text: ¶ With rejoicing you will draw water/_From the springs of salvation.

17905.text: ¶ And in that day you will say:/_“Give thanks to Jehovah, call on his name,/_Make his deeds known among the peoples!/_Declare that his name is exalted.

17906.text: ¶ Sing praises to Jehovah, for he has done magnificent things./_Let this be made known in all the earth.

17907.text: ¶ Cry out and shout for joy, you inhabitant of Zion,/_For great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.”

17908.text: §¶A pronouncement against Babylon that Isaiah the son of Aʹmoz saw in vision:

17909.text: ¶ “Raise up a signal on a mountain of bare rocks./_Call out to them, wave your hand,/_So that they may come into the entrances of the nobles.

17910.text: ¶ I have issued the command to those whom I have appointed./_I have summoned my warriors to express my anger,/_My proudly exultant ones.

17911.text: ¶ Listen! A crowd in the mountains;/_It sounds like a numerous people!/_Listen! The uproar of kingdoms,/_Of nations gathered together!/_Jehovah of armies is mustering the army for war.

17912.text: ¶ They are coming from a distant land,/_From the extremity of the heavens,/_Jehovah and the weapons of his wrath,/_To bring ruin to all the earth.

17913.text: ¶ Wail, for the day of Jehovah is near!/_It will come as a destruction from the Almighty.

17914.text: ¶ That is why all hands will go limp,/_And every man’s heart will melt with fear.

17915.text: ¶ The people are panic‑stricken./_They are seized with convulsions and pain,/_Like a woman in labor./_They look at one another in horror,/_With faces inflamed by anguish.

17916.text: ¶ Look! The day of Jehovah is coming,/_Cruel both with fury and with burning anger,/_To make the land an object of horror,/_And to annihilate the land’s sinners from it.

17917.text: ¶For the stars of the heavens and their constellations/_Will not give off their light;/_The sun will be dark when it rises,/_And the moon will not shed its light.

17918.text: ¶I will call the inhabited earth to account for its badness,/_And the wicked for their error./_I will put an end to the pride of the presumptuous,/_And I will humble the haughtiness of tyrants.

17919.text: ¶I will make mortal man scarcer than refined gold,/_And humans scarcer than the gold of Oʹphir.

17920.text: ¶That is why I will make the heavens tremble,/_And the earth will be shaken out of its place/_At the fury of Jehovah of armies in the day of his burning anger.

17921.text: ¶Like a hunted gazelle and like a flock with no one to gather them,/_Each will return to his own people;/_Each will flee to his own land.

17922.text: ¶Whoever is found will be pierced through,/_And whoever is caught will fall by the sword.

17923.text: ¶Their children will be dashed to pieces before their eyes,/_Their houses will be looted,/_And their wives will be raped.

17924.text: ¶Here I am raising up against them the Medes,/_Who regard silver as nothing/_And who take no delight in gold.

17925.text: ¶Their bows will shatter young men;/_They will show no pity on the fruit of the womb/_Nor mercy to children.

17926.text: ¶And Babylon, the most glorious of kingdoms,/_The beauty and the pride of the Chal·deʹans,/_Will be like Sodʹom and Go·morʹrah when God overthrew them.

17927.text: ¶She will never be inhabited,/_Nor will she be a place to reside in throughout all generations./_No Arab will pitch his tent there,/_And no shepherds will rest their flocks there.

17928.text: ¶The desert creatures will lie down there;/_Their houses will be filled with eagle owls./_The ostriches will reside there,/_And wild goats will skip about there.

17929.text: ¶Howling creatures will cry out in her towers,/_And jackals in her luxurious palaces./_Her time is near, and her days will not be prolonged.”

17930.text: §¶For Jehovah will show mercy to Jacob, and he will again choose Israel. He will settle them in their land, and the foreign residents will join them and attach themselves to the house of Jacob.

17931.text: And peoples will take them and bring them to their own place, and the house of Israel will possess them as male and female servants in Jehovah’s land; and they will be the captors of those who held them captive, and they will have in subjection those who were forcing them to work.

17932.text: §¶In the day when Jehovah gives you rest from your pain and from your turmoil and from the hard slavery imposed on you,

17933.text: you will recite this proverb against the king of Babylon:¶▼“How the one forcing others to work has met his end!/_How the oppression has ended!

17934.text: ¶ Jehovah has broken the rod of the wicked,/_The staff of the rulers,

17935.text: ¶ The one furiously striking peoples with unceasing blows,/_The one angrily subduing nations with relentless persecution.

17936.text: ¶ The whole earth now rests, free of disturbance./_People cry out for joy.

17937.text: ¶ Even the juniper trees rejoice over you,/_Along with the cedars of Lebʹa·non./_They say, ‘Ever since you have fallen,/_No woodcutter comes up against us.’

17938.text: ¶ Even the Grave underneath is stirred up/_To meet you when you come./_Because of you, it awakens those powerless in death,/_All the oppressive leaders of the earth./_It makes all the kings of the nations rise from their thrones.

17939.text: ¶All of them speak up and say to you,/_‘Have you also become weak like us?/_Have you become like us?

17940.text: ¶Down to the Grave your pride has been brought,/_The sound of your stringed instruments./_Maggots are spread beneath you as a bed,/_And worms are your covering.’

17941.text: ¶How you have fallen from heaven,/_O shining one, son of the dawn!/_How you have been cut down to the earth,/_You who vanquished nations!

17942.text: ¶You said in your heart, ‘I will ascend to the heavens./_Above the stars of God I will lift up my throne,/_And I will sit down on the mountain of meeting,/_In the remotest parts of the north.

17943.text: ¶I will go up above the tops of the clouds;/_I will make myself resemble the Most High.’

17944.text: ¶Instead, you will be brought down to the Grave,/_To the remotest parts of the pit.

17945.text: ¶Those seeing you will stare at you;/_They will closely examine you, saying,/_‘Is this the man who was shaking the earth,/_Who made kingdoms tremble,

17946.text: ¶Who made the inhabited earth like the wilderness/_And overthrew its cities,/_Who refused to let his prisoners go home?’

17947.text: ¶All other kings of the nations,/_Yes, all of them, lie down in glory,/_Each one in his own tomb.

17948.text: ¶But you are discarded without a grave,/_Like a detested sprout,/_Clothed with the slain who were stabbed with the sword,/_Who go down to the stones of a pit,/_Like a carcass trampled underfoot.

17949.text: ¶You will not join them in a grave,/_For you destroyed your own land,/_You killed your own people./_The offspring of evildoers will never again be named.

17950.text: ¶Prepare a slaughtering block for his sons/_Because of the guilt of their forefathers,/_So that they will not rise up and take over the earth/_And fill the land with their cities.”

17951.text: ¶“I will rise up against them,” declares Jehovah of armies.¶“And I will wipe out from Babylon name and remnant and descendants and posterity,” declares Jehovah.

17952.text: ¶“And I will make her a possession of porcupines and a region of marshes, and I will sweep her with the broom of annihilation,” declares Jehovah of armies.

17953.text: §¶Jehovah of armies has sworn:/_“Just as I have intended, so it will occur,/_And just as I have decided, that is what will come true.

17954.text: ¶I will crush the As·syrʹi·an in my land,/_And I will trample him on my mountains./_His yoke will be removed from them,/_And his load will be removed from their shoulder.”

17955.text: ¶This is what has been decided against all the earth,/_And this is the hand that is stretched out against all the nations.

17956.text: ¶For Jehovah of armies has decided,/_And who can thwart it?/_His hand is stretched out,/_And who can turn it back?

17957.text: §¶In the year that King Aʹhaz died, this pronouncement was made:

17958.text: ¶“Do not rejoice, Phi·lisʹti·a, any of you,/_Just because the staff of the one striking you has been broken./_For from the root of the serpent will come a poisonous snake,/_And its offspring will be a flying fiery snake.

17959.text: ¶While the firstborn of the lowly feed/_And the poor lie down in security,/_I will put your root to death with famine,/_And what is left of you will be killed.

17960.text: ¶Wail, O gate! Cry out, O city!/_All of you will lose heart, O Phi·lisʹti·a!/_For a smoke is coming from the north,/_And there are no stragglers in his ranks.”

17961.text: ¶How should they answer the messengers of the nation?/_That Jehovah has laid the foundation of Zion,/_And that the lowly ones of his people will take refuge in her.

17962.text: §¶A pronouncement against Moʹab:¶▼Because it has been devastated in a night,/_Ar of Moʹab has been silenced./_Because it has been devastated in a night,/_Kir of Moʹab has been silenced.

17963.text: ¶ He has gone up to the House and to Diʹbon,/_To the high places to weep./_Moʹab wails over Neʹbo and over Medʹe·ba./_Every head is shaved bald, every beard is clipped.

17964.text: ¶ In its streets they have put on sackcloth./_On their roofs and in their public squares they all wail;/_They go down weeping.

17965.text: ¶ Heshʹbon and E·le·aʹleh cry out;/_Their voice is heard as far as Jaʹhaz./_That is why the armed men of Moʹab keep shouting./_He is trembling.

17966.text: ¶ My heart cries out over Moʹab./_Its fugitives have fled as far as Zoʹar and Egʹlath‑she·liʹshi·yah./_On the ascent of Luʹhith they weep as they go up;/_On the way to Hor·o·naʹim they cry out over the catastrophe.

17967.text: ¶ For the waters of Nimʹrim are desolate;/_The green grass has dried up,/_The grass is gone and nothing green is left.

17968.text: ¶ That is why they are carrying away what is left of their stores and their riches;/_They are crossing the valley of poplars.

17969.text: ¶ For the outcry echoes throughout the territory of Moʹab./_The wailing reaches to Eg·laʹim;/_The wailing reaches to Beʹer‑eʹlim.

17970.text: ¶ For the waters of Diʹmon are full of blood,/_And I have more in store for Diʹmon:/_A lion for those of Moʹab who escape/_And for those remaining in the land.

17971.text: §¶Send a ram to the ruler of the land,/_From Seʹla through the wilderness/_To the mountain of the daughter of Zion.

17972.text: ¶ Like a bird chased away from its nest,/_So the daughters of Moʹab will be at the fords of Arʹnon.

17973.text: ¶ “Offer counsel, carry out the decision./_Make your shadow at high noon like the night./_Conceal the dispersed and do not betray those fleeing.

17974.text: ¶ May my dispersed ones reside in you, O Moʹab./_Become a place of concealment to them because of the destroyer./_The oppressor will reach his end,/_The destruction will come to an end,/_And those trampling others down will perish from the earth.

17975.text: ¶ Then a throne will be firmly established in loyal love./_The one who sits on it in the tent of David will be faithful;/_He will judge fairly and will swiftly execute righteousness.”

17976.text: ¶ We have heard about the pride of Moʹab—he is very proud—/_His haughtiness and his pride and his fury;/_But his empty talk will come to nothing.

17977.text: ¶ So Moʹab will wail for Moʹab;/_They will all wail./_Those who are stricken will moan for the raisin cakes of Kir‑harʹe·seth.

17978.text: ¶ For the terraces of Heshʹbon have withered,/_The vine of Sibʹmah,/_The rulers of the nations have trampled its bright‑red branches;/_They had reached as far as Jaʹzer;/_They had extended into the wilderness./_Its shoots had spread out and gone as far as the sea.

17979.text: ¶ That is why I will weep over the vine of Sibʹmah as I weep for Jaʹzer./_With my tears I will drench you, O Heshʹbon and E·le·aʹleh,/_Because the shouting over your summer fruit and your harvest has ended.

17980.text: ¶Rejoicing and joyfulness have been taken away from the orchard,/_And there are no songs of joy or shouting in the vineyards./_The treader no longer treads out wine in the presses,/_For I have caused the shouting to cease.

17981.text: ¶That is why deep within me I am boisterous over Moʹab,/_Like the strumming of a harp,/_And my innermost being over Kir‑harʹe·seth.

17982.text: ¶Even when Moʹab wears himself out on the high place and goes to pray in his sanctuary, he will accomplish nothing.

17983.text: ¶This is the word that Jehovah previously spoke concerning Moʹab.

17984.text: And now Jehovah says: “Within three years, like the years of a hired worker, the glory of Moʹab will be disgraced with much tumult of every sort, and those who remain will be very few and insignificant.”

17985.text: §¶A pronouncement against Damascus:¶▼“Look! Damascus will cease to be a city,/_And it will become a heap of ruins.

17986.text: ¶ The cities of A·roʹer will be abandoned;/_They will become places for flocks to lie down/_With no one to make them afraid.

17987.text: ¶ Fortified cities will disappear from Eʹphra·im,/_And the kingdom from Damascus;/_And those remaining of Syria/_Will be like the glory of the Israelites,” declares Jehovah of armies.

17988.text: ¶ “In that day the glory of Jacob will diminish,/_And his healthy body will grow thin.

17989.text: ¶ It will be as when the harvester is gathering the standing grain/_And his arm harvests the ears of grain,/_Like when one gleans grain in the Valley of Rephʹa·im.

17990.text: ¶ Only gleanings will be left,/_As when an olive tree is beaten:/_Only two or three ripe olives remain on the highest branch,/_Only four or five on its fruit‑bearing branches,” declares Jehovah the God of Israel.

17991.text: ¶In that day man will look up to his Maker, and his eyes will gaze at the Holy One of Israel.

17992.text: He will not look to the altars, the work of his hands; and he will not gaze at what his fingers have made, either the sacred poles or the incense stands.

17993.text: ¶ In that day his fortress cities will become like an abandoned site in the woodland,/_Like a branch that was abandoned before the Israelites;/_It will become a wasteland.

17994.text: ¶For you have forgotten the God of your salvation;/_You have failed to remember the Rock of your fortress./_That is why you plant beautiful plantations/_And set it with the shoot of a stranger.

17995.text: ¶In the day you carefully fence in your plantation,/_In the morning you make your seed sprout,/_But the harvest will vanish in the day of disease and incurable pain.

17996.text: §¶Listen! There is a commotion of many peoples,/_Who are as boisterous as the seas!/_There is an uproar of nations,/_Whose sound is like the roar of mighty waters!

17997.text: ¶The nations will make a sound like the roar of many waters./_He will rebuke them, and they will flee far away,/_Chased like the chaff of the mountains before a wind,/_Like a whirling thistle before a storm wind.

17998.text: ¶In the evening there is terror./_Before morning they are no more./_This is the share of those pillaging us/_And the lot of those plundering us.

17999.text: §¶Woe to the land of whirring insect wings/_In the region of the rivers of E·thi·oʹpi·a!

18000.text: ¶ It sends envoys by sea,/_Across the waters in papyrus vessels, saying:/_“Go, you swift messengers,/_To a tall and smooth‑skinned nation,/_To a people feared everywhere,/_To a strong, conquering nation,/_Whose land is washed away by rivers.”

18001.text: ¶ All you inhabitants of the land and you residents of the earth,/_What you see will be like a signal raised on the mountains,/_And you will hear a sound like the blowing of a horn.

18002.text: ¶ For this is what Jehovah said to me:/_“I will remain undisturbed and look on my established place,/_Like the shimmering heat along with the sunlight,/_Like the cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.

18003.text: ¶ For before the harvest,/_When the blossom is finished and the bloom becomes a ripening grape,/_The shoots will be cut off with pruning shears/_And the tendrils will be lopped off and removed.

18004.text: ¶ They will all be left for the birds of prey of the mountains/_And for the beasts of the earth./_The birds of prey will spend the summer on them,/_And all the beasts of the earth will spend the harvesttime on them.

18005.text: ¶ At that time a gift will be brought to Jehovah of armies,/_From a tall and smooth‑skinned nation,/_From a people feared everywhere,/_From a strong, conquering nation,/_Whose land is washed away by rivers/_To the place that bears the name of Jehovah of armies, Mount Zion.”

18006.text: §¶A pronouncement against Egypt:¶▼Look! Jehovah is riding on a swift cloud and is coming into Egypt./_The worthless gods of Egypt will tremble before him,/_And the heart of Egypt will melt within it.

18007.text: ¶ “I will incite Egyptians against Egyptians,/_And they will fight one another,/_Each against his brother and his neighbor,/_City against city, kingdom against kingdom.

18008.text: ¶ And the spirit of Egypt will become bewildered within it,/_And I will confuse its plans./_They will resort to the worthless gods,/_To the charmers and to the spirit mediums and to the fortune‑tellers.

18009.text: ¶ I will hand Egypt over to a hard master,/_And a harsh king will rule over them,” declares the true Lord, Jehovah of armies.

18010.text: ¶ The water of the sea will be dried up,/_And the river will become parched and run dry.

18011.text: ¶ And the rivers will stink;/_The Nile canals of Egypt will become low and parched./_The reeds and the rushes will decay.

18012.text: ¶ The plants along the Nile River, at the mouth of the Nile,/_And all the land sown with seed along the Nile will dry up./_It will be blown away, and it will be no more.

18013.text: ¶ And the fishermen will mourn,/_Those casting fishhooks into the Nile will lament,/_And those who spread their nets on the water will dwindle.

18014.text: ¶ Those who work in combed flax/_And those making white fabric on the loom will be put to shame.

18015.text: ¶Her weavers will be crushed;/_All the hired workers will grieve.

18016.text: ¶The princes of Zoʹan are foolish./_The wisest advisers of Pharʹaoh give unreasonable advice./_How can you say to Pharʹaoh:/_“I am a descendant of wise ones,/_A descendant of ancient kings”?

18017.text: ¶Where, then, are your wise men?/_Let them tell you if they know what Jehovah of armies has decided concerning Egypt.

18018.text: ¶The princes of Zoʹan have acted foolishly;/_The princes of Noph have been deceived;/_The chiefs of her tribes have led Egypt astray.

18019.text: ¶Jehovah has poured out on her a spirit of confusion;/_And they have led Egypt astray in whatever she does,/_Like a drunk staggering in his vomit.

18020.text: ¶And Egypt will not have any work to do,/_Whether for the head or the tail, the shoot or the rush.

18021.text: §¶In that day Egypt will become like women, trembling and terrified because of the threatening hand that Jehovah of armies raises against it.

18022.text: And the land of Judah will become a cause for terror to Egypt. They will feel dread at the mention of it because of the decision that Jehovah of armies has made against them.

18023.text: ¶In that day there will be five cities in the land of Egypt speaking the language of Caʹnaan and swearing loyalty to Jehovah of armies. One city will be called The City of Tearing Down.

18024.text: ¶In that day there will be an altar to Jehovah in the middle of the land of Egypt and a pillar to Jehovah at its boundary.

18025.text: It will be for a sign and for a witness to Jehovah of armies in the land of Egypt; for they will cry out to Jehovah because of the oppressors, and he will send them a savior, a grand one, who will save them.

18026.text: And Jehovah will become known to the Egyptians, and the Egyptians will know Jehovah in that day, and they will offer sacrifices and gifts and make a vow to Jehovah and pay it.

18027.text: Jehovah will strike Egypt, striking and healing it; and they will return to Jehovah, and he will respond to their entreaties and heal them.

18028.text: ¶In that day there will be a highway out of Egypt to As·syrʹi·a. Then As·syrʹi·a will come into Egypt, and Egypt into As·syrʹi·a, and Egypt will serve God together with As·syrʹi·a.

18029.text: In that day Israel will be the third along with Egypt and with As·syrʹi·a, a blessing in the midst of the earth,

18030.text: for Jehovah of armies will have blessed it, saying: “Blessed be my people, Egypt, and the work of my hands, As·syrʹi·a, and my inheritance, Israel.”

18031.text: §¶In the year that King Sarʹgon of As·syrʹi·a sent the Tarʹtan to Ashʹdod, he fought against Ashʹdod and captured it.

18032.text: At that time Jehovah spoke through Isaiah the son of Aʹmoz, saying: “Go, remove the sackcloth from your hips, and take your sandals off your feet.” And he did so, walking about naked and barefoot.

18033.text: ¶Jehovah then said: “Just as my servant Isaiah has walked about naked and barefoot for three years as a sign and a portent against Egypt and E·thi·oʹpi·a,

18034.text: so the king of As·syrʹi·a will lead the captives of Egypt and the exiles of E·thi·oʹpi·a, boys and old men, naked and barefoot and with exposed buttocks, the nakedness of Egypt.

18035.text: And they will be terrified and will be ashamed of E·thi·oʹpi·a their hope and of Egypt their pride.

18036.text: The inhabitants of this coastland will say in that day, ‘Look at what happened to our hope, to which we fled for help and rescue from the king of As·syrʹi·a! How will we escape now?’”

18037.text: §¶A pronouncement against the wilderness of the sea:¶▼It is coming like storm winds that sweep through in the south,/_From the wilderness, from a fearsome land.

18038.text: ¶ A harsh vision has been told to me:/_The treacherous one is acting treacherously,/_And the destroyer is destroying./_Go up, O Eʹlam! Lay siege, O Meʹdi·a!/_I will put an end to all the sighing she caused.

18039.text: ¶ That is why I am in great anguish./_Convulsions have seized me,/_Like those of a woman giving birth./_I am too distressed to hear;/_I am too disturbed to see.

18040.text: ¶ My heart falters; I shudder in terror./_The twilight I longed for makes me tremble.

18041.text: ¶ Set the table and arrange the seats!/_Eat and drink!/_Get up, you princes, anoint the shield!

18042.text: ¶ For this is what Jehovah said to me:/_“Go, post a lookout and have him report what he sees.”

18043.text: ¶ And he saw a war chariot with a team of horses,/_A war chariot of donkeys,/_A war chariot of camels./_He watched carefully, with great attentiveness.

18044.text: ¶ Then he called out like a lion:/_“Upon the watchtower, O Jehovah, I am standing constantly by day,/_And I am stationed at my guardpost every night.

18045.text: ¶ Look at what is coming:/_Men in a war chariot with a team of horses!”/_Then he spoke up and said:/_“She has fallen! Babylon has fallen!/_All the graven images of her gods he has shattered to the ground!”

18046.text: ¶O my people who have been threshed,/_The product of my threshing floor,/_I have reported to you what I have heard from Jehovah of armies, the God of Israel.

18047.text: §¶A pronouncement against Duʹmah:/_Someone is calling out to me from Seʹir:/_“Watchman, what of the night?/_Watchman, what of the night?”

18048.text: ¶The watchman said:/_“The morning is coming, and also the night./_If you would inquire, inquire./_Come again!”

18049.text: ¶A pronouncement against the desert plain:/_In the forest in the desert plain you will spend the night,/_O caravans of Deʹdan.

18050.text: ¶Bring water to meet the thirsty one,/_You inhabitants of the land of Teʹma,/_And bring bread for the one fleeing.

18051.text: ¶For they have fled from the swords, from the drawn sword,/_From the bent bow, and from the cruelty of the war.

18052.text: ¶For this is what Jehovah said to me: “Within one year, like the years of a hired worker, all the glory of Keʹdar will come to an end.

18053.text: The remaining bowmen of the warriors of Keʹdar will be few, for Jehovah the God of Israel has spoken.”

18054.text: §¶A pronouncement about the Valley of Vision:¶▼What is the matter with you that you have all gone up to the roofs?

18055.text: ¶ You were full of turmoil,/_A boisterous city, an exultant town./_Your slain were not slain with the sword,/_Nor did they die in battle.

18056.text: ¶ All your dictators have fled together./_They were taken prisoner without need of a bow./_All who were found were taken prisoner,/_Even though they had fled far away.

18057.text: ¶ That is why I said: “Turn your eyes away from me,/_And I will weep bitterly./_Do not insist on comforting me/_Over the destruction of the daughter of my people.

18058.text: ¶ For it is a day of confusion and of defeat and of panic,/_From the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies,/_In the Valley of Vision./_There is a demolishing of the wall/_And a cry to the mountain.

18059.text: ¶ Eʹlam picks up the quiver/_With manned chariots and horses,/_And Kir uncovers the shield.

18060.text: ¶ Your choicest valleys/_Will become full of war chariots,/_And the horses will take their positions at the gate,

18061.text: ¶ And the screen of Judah will be removed.¶►“In that day you will look toward the armory of the House of the Forest,

18062.text: and you will see the many breaches of the City of David. And you will collect the waters of the lower pool.

18063.text: You will count the houses of Jerusalem, and you will pull down the houses to reinforce the wall.

18064.text: And you will make a basin between the two walls for the water of the old pool, but you will not look to its Grand Maker, and you will not see the One who formed it long ago.

18065.text: ¶In that day the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies,/_Will call for weeping and mourning,/_For shaved heads and the wearing of sackcloth.

18066.text: ¶But instead, there is celebration and rejoicing,/_The killing of cattle and the slaughtering of sheep,/_The eating of meat and the drinking of wine./_‘Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we will die.’”

18067.text: ¶Then Jehovah of armies revealed himself in my ears: “‘This error will not be atoned in your behalf until you people die,’ says the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies.”

18068.text: §¶This is what the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies, says: “Go in to this steward, to Shebʹna, who is in charge of the house, and say,

18069.text: ‘What is your interest here, and who is there of interest to you here, that you hewed out a burial place here for yourself?’ He is hewing out his burial place in a high place; he is cutting out a resting‑place for himself in a crag.

18070.text: ‘Look! Jehovah will hurl you down violently, O man, and seize you forcibly.

18071.text: He will certainly wrap you up tightly and hurl you like a ball into a wide land. There you will die, and there your glorious chariots will be, a disgrace to your master’s house.

18072.text: And I will depose you from your position and throw you out of your office.

18073.text: ¶“‘In that day I will call my servant E·liʹa·kim the son of Hil·kiʹah,

18074.text: and I will clothe him with your robe and firmly bind your sash around him, and I will give your authority into his hand. And he will be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.

18075.text: And I will put the key of the house of David on his shoulder. He will open and no one will shut; and he will shut and no one will open.

18076.text: I will drive him in as a peg in a lasting place, and he will become as a throne of glory to the house of his father.

18077.text: And they will hang on him all the glory of the house of his father, the descendants and the offspring, all the small vessels, the bowl‑shaped vessels, as well as all the large jars.

18078.text: ¶“‘In that day,’ declares Jehovah of armies, ‘the peg that is driven in a lasting place will be removed, and it will be cut down and fall, and the load that it supported will fall to ruin, for Jehovah himself has spoken.’”

18079.text: §¶A pronouncement about Tyre:¶▼Wail, you ships of Tarʹshish!/_For the port has been destroyed; it cannot be entered./_From the land of Kitʹtim it has been revealed to them.

18080.text: ¶ Be silent, you inhabitants of the coastland./_The merchants from Siʹdon who cross the sea have filled you.

18081.text: ¶ Over many waters went the grain of Shiʹhor,/_The harvest of the Nile, her revenue,/_Bringing the profit of the nations.

18082.text: ¶ Be ashamed, O Siʹdon, you stronghold of the sea,/_Because the sea has said:/_“I have not had birth pains, and I have not given birth,/_Nor have I brought up young men or raised young women.”

18083.text: ¶ As when they heard the report about Egypt,/_People will be in anguish over the report about Tyre.

18084.text: ¶ Cross over to Tarʹshish!/_Wail, you inhabitants of the coastland!

18085.text: ¶ Is this your city that was exultant from long ago, from her early times?/_Her feet used to take her to distant lands to reside.

18086.text: ¶ Who has decided this against Tyre,/_The bestower of crowns,/_Whose merchants were princes,/_Whose tradesmen were honored in all the earth?

18087.text: ¶ Jehovah of armies himself has decided this,/_To profane her pride over all her beauty,/_To humiliate all those who were honored throughout the earth.

18088.text: ¶Cross over your land like the Nile River, O daughter of Tarʹshish./_There is no longer any shipyard.

18089.text: ¶He has stretched his hand out over the sea;/_He has shaken kingdoms./_Jehovah has ordered the annihilation of Phoe·niʹcia’s strongholds.

18090.text: ¶And he says: “You will exult no more,/_O oppressed one, the virgin daughter of Siʹdon./_Get up, cross over to Kitʹtim./_Even there you will find no rest.”

18091.text: ¶Look! The land of the Chal·deʹans./_This is the people—As·syrʹi·a was not the one—/_They made her a place for those haunting the desert./_They have erected their siege towers;/_They have stripped bare her fortified towers,/_Reducing her to a crumbling ruin.

18092.text: ¶Wail, you ships of Tarʹshish,/_For your stronghold has been destroyed.

18093.text: ¶In that day Tyre will be forgotten for 70 years, the same as the lifetime of one king. At the end of 70 years, it will happen to Tyre as in the song of a prostitute:

18094.text: ¶“Take a harp, go around the city, O forgotten prostitute./_Play your harp skillfully;/_Sing many songs,/_So that they will remember you.”

18095.text: ¶At the end of 70 years, Jehovah will turn his attention to Tyre, and she will return to her hire and prostitute herself with all the world’s kingdoms on the face of the earth.

18096.text: But her profit and her hire will become something holy to Jehovah. It will not be stored or laid away, because her hire will be for those dwelling before Jehovah, so that they may eat to satisfaction and wear elegant clothing.

18097.text: §¶Look! Jehovah is emptying the land and making it desolate./_He turns it upside down and scatters its inhabitants.

18098.text: ¶ It will be the same for everyone:/_The people as well as the priest,/_The servant and his master,/_The servant and her mistress,/_The buyer and the seller,/_The lender and the borrower,/_The creditor and the debtor.

18099.text: ¶ The land will be completely emptied;/_It will be completely plundered,/_For Jehovah has spoken this word.

18100.text: ¶ The land mourns; it is wasting away./_The productive land withers; it is fading away./_The prominent people of the land wither.

18101.text: ¶ The land has been polluted by its inhabitants,/_For they have bypassed the laws,/_Changed the regulation,/_And broken the lasting covenant.

18102.text: ¶ That is why the curse devours the land,/_And those inhabiting it are held guilty./_That is why the inhabitants of the land have dwindled,/_And very few men are left.

18103.text: ¶ The new wine mourns, the vine withers,/_And all those cheerful at heart are sighing.

18104.text: ¶ The joy of the tambourines has ceased;/_The noise of the revelers has ended;/_The happy sound of the harp has ceased.

18105.text: ¶ They drink wine without song,/_And alcohol tastes bitter to those drinking it.

18106.text: ¶The deserted town is broken down;/_Every house is shut up so that no one can enter.

18107.text: ¶They cry out for wine in the streets./_All rejoicing has disappeared;/_The joy of the land has gone.

18108.text: ¶The city is left in ruins;/_The gate has been crushed to a heap of rubble.

18109.text: ¶For this is how it will be in the land, among the peoples:/_As when an olive tree is beaten,/_Like the gleaning when the grape harvest comes to an end.

18110.text: ¶They will raise their voice,/_They will shout joyfully./_From the sea they will proclaim the majesty of Jehovah.

18111.text: ¶That is why they will glorify Jehovah in the region of light;/_In the islands of the sea they will glorify the name of Jehovah the God of Israel.

18112.text: ¶From the ends of the earth we hear songs:/_“Glory to the Righteous One!”/_But I say: “I am wasting away, I am wasting away!/_Woe to me! The treacherous have acted treacherously;/_With treachery the treacherous have acted treacherously.”

18113.text: ¶Terror and pits and traps await you, inhabitant of the land.

18114.text: ¶Anyone fleeing from the sound of terror will fall into the pit,/_And anyone coming up from the pit will be caught in the trap./_For the floodgates above will be opened,/_And the foundations of the land will quake.

18115.text: ¶The land has burst apart;/_The land has been shaken up;/_The land convulses violently.

18116.text: ¶The land staggers like a drunken man,/_And it sways back and forth like a hut in the wind./_Its transgression weighs heavily on it,/_And it will fall, so that it will not rise up again.

18117.text: ¶In that day Jehovah will turn his attention to the army of the heights above/_And to the kings of the earth upon the earth.

18118.text: ¶And they will be gathered together/_Like prisoners gathered into a pit,/_And they will be shut up in the dungeon;/_After many days they will be given attention.

18119.text: ¶The full moon will be abashed,/_And the shining sun will be ashamed,/_For Jehovah of armies has become King in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem,/_Glorious before the elders of his people.

18120.text: §¶O Jehovah, you are my God./_I exalt you, I praise your name,/_For you have done wonderful things,/_Things purposed from ancient times,/_In faithfulness, in trustworthiness.

18121.text: ¶ For you have turned a city into a pile of stones,/_A fortified town into a crumbling ruin./_The foreigner’s tower is a city no more;/_It will never be rebuilt.

18122.text: ¶ That is why a strong people will glorify you;/_The city of tyrannical nations will fear you.

18123.text: ¶ For you have become a stronghold to the lowly,/_A stronghold to the poor in his distress,/_A refuge from the rainstorm,/_And a shade from the heat./_When the blast of the tyrants is like a rainstorm against a wall,

18124.text: ¶ As the heat in a parched land,/_You subdue the uproar of strangers./_Like heat is subdued by the shadow of a cloud,/_So the song of the tyrants is silenced.

18125.text: ¶ In this mountain Jehovah of armies will make for all the peoples/_A banquet of rich dishes,/_A banquet of fine wine,/_Of rich dishes filled with marrow,/_Of fine, filtered wine.

18126.text: ¶ In this mountain he will do away with the shroud that is enveloping all the peoples/_And the covering that is woven over all the nations.

18127.text: ¶ He will swallow up death forever,/_And the Sovereign Lord Jehovah will wipe away the tears from all faces./_The reproach of his people he will take away from all the earth,/_For Jehovah himself has spoken it.

18128.text: ¶ In that day they will say:/_“Look! This is our God!/_We have hoped in him,/_And he will save us./_This is Jehovah!/_We have hoped in him./_Let us be joyful and rejoice in the salvation by him.”

18129.text: ¶For the hand of Jehovah will rest on this mountain,/_And Moʹab will be trampled on in its place/_Like straw trampled into a pile of manure.

18130.text: ¶He will slap out his hands into it/_Like a swimmer slapping out his hands to swim,/_And he will bring down its haughtiness/_With the skillful movements of his hands.

18131.text: ¶And the fortified city, with your high walls of security,/_He will bring down;/_He will knock it down to the ground, to the very dust.

18132.text: §¶In that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah:¶▼“We have a strong city./_He makes salvation its walls and its ramparts.

18133.text: ¶ Open up the gates so that the righteous nation may enter,/_A nation that is keeping faithful conduct.

18134.text: ¶ You will safeguard those who fully lean on you;/_You will give them continuous peace,/_Because it is in you that they trust.

18135.text: ¶ Trust in Jehovah forever,/_For Jah Jehovah is the eternal Rock.

18136.text: ¶ For he has brought low those inhabiting the height, the lofty city./_He brings it down,/_He brings it down to the earth;/_He casts it down to the dust.

18137.text: ¶ The foot will trample it,/_The feet of the afflicted, the steps of the lowly.”

18138.text: ¶ The path of the righteous one is upright./_Because you are upright,/_You will smooth out the course of the righteous.

18139.text: ¶ As we follow the path of your judgments, O Jehovah,/_Our hope is in you./_We long for your name and your memorial.

18140.text: ¶ In the night I long for you with my whole being,/_Yes, my spirit keeps looking for you;/_For when there are judgments from you for the earth,/_The inhabitants of the land learn about righteousness.

18141.text: ¶Even if the wicked is shown favor,/_He will not learn righteousness./_Even in the land of uprightness he will act wickedly,/_And he will not see the majesty of Jehovah.

18142.text: ¶O Jehovah, your hand is raised, but they do not see it./_They will see your zeal for your people and be put to shame./_Yes, the fire for your adversaries will consume them.

18143.text: ¶O Jehovah, you will grant us peace,/_Because everything we have done/_You have accomplished for us.

18144.text: ¶O Jehovah our God, other masters besides you have ruled over us,/_But we make mention of your name alone.

18145.text: ¶They are dead; they will not live./_Powerless in death, they will not rise up./_For you have turned your attention to them/_To annihilate them and destroy all mention of them.

18146.text: ¶You have enlarged the nation, O Jehovah,/_You have enlarged the nation;/_You have glorified yourself./_You have greatly extended all the borders of the land.

18147.text: ¶O Jehovah, during distress they turned to you;/_They poured out their prayer in a whisper when you disciplined them.

18148.text: ¶Just as a pregnant woman about to give birth/_Has labor pains and cries out in pain,/_So we have been because of you, O Jehovah.

18149.text: ¶We became pregnant, we had labor pains,/_But it is as if we have given birth to wind./_We have not brought salvation to the land,/_And no one is born to inhabit the land.

18150.text: ¶“Your dead will live./_My corpses will rise up./_Awake and shout joyfully,/_You residents in the dust!/_For your dew is as the dew of the morning,/_And the earth will let those powerless in death come to life.

18151.text: ¶Go, my people, enter your inner rooms,/_And shut your doors behind you./_Hide yourself for a brief moment/_Until the wrath has passed by.

18152.text: ¶For look! Jehovah is coming from his place/_To call the inhabitants of the land to account for their error,/_And the land will expose her bloodshed/_And will no longer cover over her slain.”

18153.text: §¶In that day Jehovah, with his harsh and great and strong sword,/_Will turn his attention to Le·viʹa·than, the gliding serpent,/_To Le·viʹa·than, the twisting serpent,/_And he will kill the monster that is in the sea.

18154.text: §¶ In that day sing to her:/_“A vineyard of foaming wine!

18155.text: ¶ I, Jehovah, am safeguarding her./_Every moment I water her./_I safeguard her night and day,/_So that no one may harm her.

18156.text: ¶ There is no wrath in me./_Who will confront me with thornbushes and weeds in the battle?/_I will trample them and set them on fire all together.

18157.text: ¶ Otherwise, let him hold fast to my stronghold./_Let him make peace with me;/_Peace let him make with me.”

18158.text: ¶ In the coming days Jacob will take root,/_Israel will blossom and sprout,/_And they will fill the land with produce.

18159.text: ¶ Must he be struck with the stroke of the one striking him?/_Or must he be killed as with the slaughter of his slain?

18160.text: ¶ With a startling cry you will contend with her when sending her away./_He will expel her with his fierce blast in the day of the east wind.
