18161.text: ¶ So in this way the error of Jacob will be atoned for,/_And this will be the full fruitage when his sin is taken away:/_He will make all the stones of the altar/_Like chalkstones that have been pulverized,/_And no sacred poles or incense stands will be left.

18162.text: ¶For the fortified city will be deserted;/_The pastures will be forsaken and abandoned like a wilderness./_There the calf will graze and lie down/_And will consume her branches.

18163.text: ¶When her twigs have dried up,/_Women will come and break them off,/_Making fires with them./_For this people is without understanding./_That is why their Maker will show them no mercy,/_And the One who formed them will show them no favor.

18164.text: ¶In that day Jehovah will beat out the fruit from the flowing stream of the River to the Wadi of Egypt, and you will be gathered up one after the other, O people of Israel.

18165.text: In that day a great horn will be blown, and those who are perishing in the land of As·syrʹi·a and those dispersed in the land of Egypt will come and bow down to Jehovah in the holy mountain in Jerusalem.

18166.text: §¶Woe to the showy crown of the drunkards of Eʹphra·im/_And the fading blossom of its glorious beauty,/_Which is on the head of the fertile valley of those overcome with wine!

18167.text: ¶ Look! Jehovah has someone strong and mighty./_Like a thundering hailstorm, a destructive windstorm,/_Like a thunderstorm of powerful floodwaters,/_He will forcefully hurl it down to the earth.

18168.text: ¶ The showy crowns of the drunkards of Eʹphra·im/_Will be trampled underfoot.

18169.text: ¶ And the fading flower of its glorious beauty,/_Which is on the head of the fertile valley,/_Will become like the early fig before summer./_When someone sees it, he swallows it as soon as it is in his hand.

18170.text: ¶In that day Jehovah of armies will become a glorious crown and a beautiful garland to those left of his people.

18171.text: And he will become a spirit of justice to the one who sits in judgment and a source of mightiness to those who repel the attack at the gate.

18172.text: §¶ And these also go astray because of wine;/_Their alcoholic beverages make them stagger./_Priest and prophet go astray because of alcohol;/_The wine confuses them,/_And they stagger from their alcohol;/_Their vision makes them go astray,/_And they stumble in judgment.

18173.text: ¶ For their tables are full of filthy vomit/_—There is no place without it.

18174.text: ¶ To whom will one impart knowledge,/_And to whom will one explain the message?/_To those who have just been weaned from milk,/_Those just taken away from the breasts?

18175.text: ¶For it is “command after command, command after command,/_Line by line, line by line,/_A little here, a little there.”

18176.text: ¶So by means of those with stammering speech and a foreign language, he will speak to this people.

18177.text: He once told them: “This is the resting‑place. Let the weary one rest; this is the place of refreshment,” but they refused to listen.

18178.text: So to them the word of Jehovah will be:¶▼“Command after command, command after command,/_Line by line, line by line,/_A little here, a little there,”/_So that when they walk,/_They will stumble and fall backward/_And be broken and ensnared and caught.

18179.text: §¶So hear the word of Jehovah, you boasters,/_You rulers of this people in Jerusalem,

18180.text: ¶For you men say:/_“We have made a covenant with Death,/_And with the Grave we have made an agreement./_When the raging flash flood passes through,/_It will not reach us,/_For we have made a lie our refuge/_And we have hidden ourselves in falsehood.”

18181.text: ¶Therefore this is what the Sovereign Lord Jehovah says:/_“Here I am laying as a foundation in Zion a tested stone,/_The precious cornerstone of a sure foundation./_No one exercising faith will panic.

18182.text: ¶And I will make justice the measuring line/_And righteousness the leveling tool./_The hail will sweep away the refuge of lies,/_And the waters will flood out the hiding place.

18183.text: ¶Your covenant with Death will be dissolved,/_And your agreement with the Grave will not stand./_When the raging flash flood passes through,/_You will be crushed by it.

18184.text: ¶As often as it passes through,/_It will sweep you away;/_For it will pass through morning after morning,/_During the day and during the night./_Only terror will make them understand what was heard.”

18185.text: ¶For the bed is too short to stretch out on,/_And the woven sheet is too narrow to wrap up in.

18186.text: ¶For Jehovah will rise up as at Mount Pe·raʹzim;/_He will rouse himself as in the valley near Gibʹe·on,/_That he may do his deed—his strange deed—/_And that he may carry out his work—his unusual work.

18187.text: ¶Now do not scoff,/_So that your bonds may not be further tightened,/_For I have heard from the Sovereign Lord, Jehovah of armies,/_That an extermination has been determined for all the land.

18188.text: §¶Give ear and listen to my voice;/_Pay attention and listen to what I say.

18189.text: ¶Does the plower keep plowing all day before he sows seed?/_Does he continually break up and harrow his ground?

18190.text: ¶When he has smoothed out its surface,/_Does he not then scatter black cumin and sow cumin,/_And does he not plant wheat, millet, and barley in their places/_And spelt around the edges?

18191.text: ¶For He teaches him the right way;/_His God instructs him.

18192.text: ¶For black cumin is not crushed with a threshing sledge,/_And a wagon wheel is not driven over cumin./_Rather, black cumin is beaten out with a rod,/_And cumin with a staff.

18193.text: ¶Does a person crush grain for bread?/_No, he does not thresh it incessantly;/_And when he drives the roller of his wagon over it with his horses,/_He does not crush it.

18194.text: ¶This also comes from Jehovah of armies,/_Whose counsel is wonderful/_And whose achievements are great.

18195.text: §¶“Woe to Arʹi·el, Arʹi·el, the city where David encamped!/_Continue year after year;/_Let the cycle of festivals continue.

18196.text: ¶ But I will bring distress on Arʹi·el,/_And there will be mourning and lamentation,/_And she will become to me like an altar hearth of God.

18197.text: ¶ I will encamp on all sides against you,/_And I will besiege you with a palisade/_And raise up siegeworks against you.

18198.text: ¶ You will be brought low;/_From the ground you will speak,/_And what you say will be muffled by dust./_Your voice will come from the ground/_Like the voice of a spirit medium,/_And your words will chirp from the dust.

18199.text: ¶ The crowd of your enemies will be like fine powder,/_The crowd of the tyrants just like the blowing chaff./_And it will happen in an instant, suddenly.

18200.text: ¶ Jehovah of armies will give you his attention/_With thunder and earthquake and a great noise,/_With storm wind and tempest and the flames of a consuming fire.”

18201.text: ¶ Then the crowd of all the nations waging war against Arʹi·el/_—All those waging war against her,/_The siege towers against her,/_And those bringing distress on her—/_Will become like a dream, a vision of the night.

18202.text: ¶ Yes, it will be just as when someone hungry dreams that he is eating,/_But he wakes up hungry,/_And as when someone thirsty dreams that he is drinking,/_But he wakes up tired and thirsty./_So it will happen with the crowd of all the nations/_That wage war against Mount Zion.

18203.text: ¶ Be stunned and amazed;/_Blind yourselves and be blinded./_They are drunk, but not with wine;/_They are staggering, but not from alcohol.

18204.text: ¶For Jehovah has poured a spirit of deep sleep on you;/_He has closed your eyes, the prophets,/_And he has covered your heads, the visionaries.

18205.text: ¶Every vision becomes for you like the words of a sealed book. When they give it to someone who can read, saying: “Read this out loud, please,” he will say: “I cannot, for it is sealed up.”

18206.text: And when they give the book to someone who cannot read, saying: “Read this, please,” he will say: “I cannot read at all.”

18207.text: ¶Jehovah says: “This people approaches me with their mouth/_And they honor me with their lips,/_But their heart is far removed from me;/_And their fear of me is based on commands of men that they have been taught.

18208.text: ¶Therefore, I am the One who will again do wonderful things with this people,/_With wonder upon wonder;/_And the wisdom of their wise men will perish,/_And the understanding of their discreet men will be hidden.”

18209.text: ¶Woe to those who go to great lengths to conceal their plans from Jehovah./_Their deeds are done in a dark place,/_While they say: “Who sees us?/_Who knows about us?”

18210.text: ¶How you twist things!/_Should the potter be regarded the same as the clay?/_Should what is made say about its maker:/_“He did not make me”?/_And does what is formed say about its former:/_“He shows no understanding”?

18211.text: §¶In just a short time, Lebʹa·non will be turned into an orchard,/_And the orchard will be regarded as a forest.

18212.text: ¶In that day the deaf will hear the words of the book,/_And out of the gloom and darkness the eyes of the blind will see.

18213.text: ¶The meek will rejoice greatly in Jehovah,/_And the poor among men will be joyful in the Holy One of Israel.

18214.text: ¶For the tyrant will be no more,/_The boaster will come to his finish,/_And all those keeping alert to do harm will be destroyed,

18215.text: ¶Those who with a false word make others guilty,/_Who lay traps for the defender in the city gate,/_And who with empty arguments deny justice to the righteous one.

18216.text: ¶So this is what Jehovah, who redeemed Abraham, says to the house of Jacob:¶▼“Jacob will no longer be ashamed,/_And no more will his face grow pale.

18217.text: ¶For when he sees his children,/_Who are the work of my hands, in his midst,/_They will sanctify my name;/_Yes, they will sanctify the Holy One of Jacob,/_And they will stand in awe of the God of Israel.

18218.text: ¶Those who are wayward in spirit will acquire understanding,/_And those who complain will accept instruction.”

18219.text: §¶“Woe to the stubborn sons,” declares Jehovah,/_“Who carry out plans that are not mine,/_Who make alliances, but not by my spirit,/_In order to add sin to sin.

18220.text: ¶ They go down to Egypt without consulting me,/_To take shelter under Pharʹaoh’s protection/_And to take refuge in the shadow of Egypt!

18221.text: ¶ But the protection of Pharʹaoh will become for you a reason for shame,/_And refuge in Egypt’s shadow a cause for humiliation.

18222.text: ¶ For his princes are in Zoʹan,/_And his envoys have reached Haʹnes.

18223.text: ¶ They will all be put to shame/_By a people who can bring no benefit to them,/_Who offer no help and no benefit,/_Only shame and disgrace.”

18224.text: ¶A pronouncement against the beasts of the south:¶▼Through the land of distress and hardship,/_Of the lion, the roaring lion,/_Of the viper and the flying fiery snake,/_They carry their wealth on the backs of donkeys/_And their supplies on the humps of camels./_But these things will not benefit the people.

18225.text: ¶ For Egypt’s help is completely useless./_So I have called this one: “Raʹhab, who sits still.”

18226.text: §¶ “Now go, write it on a tablet in their presence,/_And inscribe it in a book,/_So that it may serve for a future day/_As a permanent witness.

18227.text: ¶ For they are a rebellious people, deceitful sons,/_Sons who are unwilling to hear the law of Jehovah.

18228.text: ¶They say to the seers, ‘Do not see,’/_And to the visionaries, ‘Do not tell us truthful visions./_Tell us flattering things; envision deceptive illusions.

18229.text: ¶Turn aside from the way; deviate from the path./_Quit putting before us the Holy One of Israel.’”

18230.text: ¶Therefore this is what the Holy One of Israel says:/_“Since you reject this word/_And you trust in fraud and deceit/_And you rely on these,

18231.text: ¶So this error will be for you like a broken wall,/_Like a bulging high wall ready to fall./_It will crash suddenly, in an instant.

18232.text: ¶It will be broken like a large potter’s jar,/_So completely smashed that no fragment among its pieces will be left/_To rake the fire from the fireplace/_Or to scoop water from a puddle.”

18233.text: §¶For this is what the Sovereign Lord Jehovah, the Holy One of Israel, says:/_“By returning to me and resting, you will be saved;/_Your strength will be in keeping calm and showing trust.”/_But you were unwilling.

18234.text: ¶Instead, you said: “No, we will flee on horses!”  /_So flee you will.¶►“And on swift horses we will ride!”  /_So those pursuing you will be swift.

18235.text: ¶A thousand will tremble at the threat of one;/_At the threat of five you will flee/_Until what is left of you is like a mast on the top of a mountain,/_Like a signal pole on a hill.

18236.text: §¶But Jehovah is waiting patiently to show you favor,/_And he will rise up to show you mercy./_For Jehovah is a God of justice./_Happy are all those keeping in expectation of him.

18237.text: ¶When the people dwell in Zion, in Jerusalem, you will by no means weep. He will surely show you favor at the sound of your cry for help; he will answer you as soon as he hears it.

18238.text: Though Jehovah will give you bread in the form of distress and water in the form of oppression, your Grand Instructor will no longer hide himself, and you will see your Grand Instructor with your own eyes.

18239.text: And your own ears will hear a word behind you saying, “This is the way. Walk in it,” in case you should go to the right or in case you should go to the left.

18240.text: ¶And you will defile the silver overlay of your graven images and the golden plating of your metal statues. You will cast them away like a menstrual cloth and say to them, “Be gone!”

18241.text: And he will give the rain for the seed you sow in the ground, and the bread that the ground produces will be abundant and rich. In that day your livestock will graze in spacious pastures.

18242.text: And the cattle and the donkeys that work the ground will eat fodder seasoned with sorrel, which was winnowed with the shovel and the pitchfork.

18243.text: And on every tall mountain and on every high hill will be streams and watercourses, in the day of the great slaughter when the towers fall.

18244.text: And the light of the full moon will become like the light of the sun; and the light of the sun will become seven times stronger, like the light of seven days, in the day that Jehovah binds up the breakdown of his people and heals the severe wound from the blow he inflicted.

18245.text: §¶Look! The name of Jehovah is coming from far away,/_Burning with his anger and with heavy clouds./_His lips are full of indignation,/_And his tongue is like a consuming fire.

18246.text: ¶His spirit is like a flooding torrent that reaches clear to the neck,/_To shake the nations in a sieve of destruction;/_And the peoples will have a bridle in their jaws that leads them astray.

18247.text: ¶But your song will be like the one sung in the night/_When you prepare for a festival,/_And your heart will rejoice like one/_Who walks with a flute/_On his way to the mountain of Jehovah, to the Rock of Israel.

18248.text: ¶Jehovah will make his majestic voice heard/_And reveal his arm as it descends in the heat of anger,/_With the flame of a consuming fire,/_A cloudburst and a thunderstorm and hailstones.

18249.text: ¶For because of the voice of Jehovah, As·syrʹi·a will be struck with terror;/_He will strike it with a rod.

18250.text: ¶And every swing of his rod of punishment/_That Jehovah will bring down on As·syrʹi·a/_Will be accompanied by tambourines and harps/_As he brandishes his arm against them in battle.

18251.text: ¶For his Toʹpheth is already prepared;/_It is also made ready for the king./_He has made the woodpile deep and wide,/_With an abundance of fire and wood./_The breath of Jehovah, like a torrent of sulfur,/_Will set fire to it.

18252.text: §¶Woe to those who go down to Egypt for assistance,/_Who rely on horses,/_Who trust in war chariots because they are numerous,/_And in warhorses because they are mighty./_But they do not look to the Holy One of Israel,/_And they do not search for Jehovah.

18253.text: ¶ But he is also wise and will bring calamity,/_And he will not take back his words./_He will rise up against the house of evildoers/_And against those who help wrongdoers.

18254.text: ¶ The Egyptians, though, are mere men and not God;/_Their horses are flesh and not spirit./_When Jehovah stretches out his hand,/_Whoever offers help will stumble/_And whoever is helped will fall;/_They will all perish at the same time.

18255.text: ¶ For this is what Jehovah has said to me:/_“Just as the lion growls, a strong young lion, over its prey,/_When a whole group of shepherds is called together against it,/_And it is not terrified by their voice/_Or daunted by their commotion,/_So will Jehovah of armies come down to wage war/_Over Mount Zion and over her hill.

18256.text: ¶ Like swooping birds, so Jehovah of armies will defend Jerusalem./_He will defend her and save her./_He will spare her and rescue her.”

18257.text: ¶“Return to the One against whom you have blatantly revolted, O people of Israel.

18258.text: For in that day each one will reject his worthless gods of silver and his valueless gods of gold, which your own hands sinfully made.

18259.text: ¶ And the As·syrʹi·an will fall by the sword, not of a man;/_And a sword, not of a human, will devour him./_He will flee because of the sword,/_And his young men will be put to forced labor.

18260.text: ¶ His crag will pass away because of sheer fright,/_And his princes will be terrified because of the signal pole,” declares Jehovah,/_Whose light is in Zion and whose furnace is in Jerusalem.

18261.text: §¶Look! A king will reign for righteousness,/_And princes will rule for justice.

18262.text: ¶ And each one will be like a hiding place from the wind,/_A place of concealment from the rainstorm,/_Like streams of water in a waterless land,/_Like the shadow of a massive crag in a parched land.

18263.text: ¶ Then the eyes of those seeing will no longer be pasted shut,/_And the ears of those hearing will pay attention.

18264.text: ¶ The heart of those who are impetuous will ponder over knowledge,/_And the stammering tongue will speak fluently and clearly.

18265.text: ¶ The senseless one will no longer be called generous,/_And the unprincipled man will not be called noble;

18266.text: ¶ For the senseless one will speak nonsense,/_And his heart will devise harmful things,/_To promote apostasy and to speak what is wayward against Jehovah,/_To cause the hungry one to go unfed/_And to deprive the thirsty one of something to drink.

18267.text: ¶ The devices of the unprincipled man are bad;/_He promotes shameful conduct/_To ruin the afflicted one with lies,/_Even when the poor speaks what is right.

18268.text: ¶ But the generous one has generous intentions,/_And in generous endeavors he perseveres.

18269.text: §¶ “You complacent women, get up and listen to my voice!/_You carefree daughters, pay attention to what I say!

18270.text: ¶In a little over a year, you who are carefree will shudder,/_Because no fruit will have been gathered when the grape harvest ends.

18271.text: ¶Tremble, you complacent women!/_Shudder, you who are carefree!/_Strip yourselves bare,/_And put sackcloth around your hips.

18272.text: ¶Beat your breasts in lamentation/_Over the desirable fields and the fruitful vine.

18273.text: ¶For the ground of my people will be covered with thorns and briars;/_They will cover all the houses of rejoicing,/_Yes, the city of exultation.

18274.text: ¶For the fortified tower has been forsaken;/_The noisy city has been abandoned./_Oʹphel and the watchtower have become a permanent wasteland,/_A delight for wild donkeys,/_A pasture for the flocks,

18275.text: §¶Until the spirit is poured out on us from above,/_And the wilderness becomes an orchard,/_And the orchard is regarded as a forest.

18276.text: ¶Then justice will reside in the wilderness,/_And righteousness will dwell in the orchard.

18277.text: ¶The result of true righteousness will be peace,/_And the fruitage of true righteousness will be lasting tranquillity and security.

18278.text: ¶My people will dwell in a peaceful abiding place,/_In secure dwellings and in tranquil resting‑places.

18279.text: ¶But the hail will flatten the forest,/_And the city will be completely leveled.

18280.text: ¶Happy are you who sow seed alongside all waters,/_Who send out the bull and the donkey.”

18281.text: §¶Woe to you, you destroyer who has not been destroyed;/_You betrayer who has not been betrayed!/_When you finish destroying, you will be destroyed./_When you finish betraying, you will be betrayed.

18282.text: ¶ O Jehovah, show us favor./_Our hope is in you./_Become our arm every morning,/_Yes, our salvation in the time of distress.

18283.text: ¶ At the sound of turmoil peoples flee./_When you rise up, nations scatter.

18284.text: ¶ As the voracious locusts gather, so your spoil will be gathered;/_People will rush on it like swarms of locusts.

18285.text: ¶ Jehovah will be exalted,/_For he resides in the heights above./_He will fill Zion with justice and righteousness.

18286.text: ¶ He is the stability of your times;/_An abundance of salvation, wisdom, knowledge, and the fear of Jehovah/_—This is his treasure.

18287.text: ¶ Look! Their heroes cry out in the street;/_The messengers of peace weep bitterly.

18288.text: ¶ The highways are deserted;/_There is no one traveling on the pathways./_He has broken the covenant;/_He has rejected the cities;/_He shows no regard for mortal man.

18289.text: ¶ The land mourns and withers away./_Lebʹa·non is ashamed; it has decayed./_Sharʹon has become like the desert,/_And Baʹshan and Carʹmel shake off their leaves.

18290.text: ¶“Now I will rise up,” says Jehovah,/_“Now I will exalt myself;/_Now I will magnify myself.

18291.text: ¶You conceive dried grass and give birth to stubble./_Your own spirit will consume you like a fire.

18292.text: ¶And peoples will become as the burnings of lime./_As thorns cut down, they will be set ablaze with fire.

18293.text: ¶You who are far away, listen to what I will do!/_And you who are nearby, acknowledge my might!

18294.text: ¶The sinners in Zion are in dread;/_Trembling has seized the apostates:/_‘Who of us can live where there is a consuming fire?/_Who of us can live with unquenchable flames?’

18295.text: ¶The one who walks in continual righteousness,/_Who speaks what is upright,/_Who rejects dishonest, fraudulent gain,/_Whose hands refuse a bribe rather than grabbing it,/_Who closes his ear to talk of bloodshed,/_And who shuts his eyes to avoid seeing what is bad

18296.text: ¶—He will reside in the heights;/_His secure refuge will be in rocky strongholds,/_His bread will be provided,/_And his water supply will never fail.”

18297.text: ¶Your eyes will behold a king in his splendor;/_They will see a land far away.

18298.text: ¶In your heart you will recall the terror:/_“Where is the secretary?/_Where is the one who weighed out the tribute?/_Where is the one who counted the towers?”

18299.text: ¶You will no more see the insolent people,/_A people whose language is too obscure to comprehend,/_Whose stammering tongue you cannot understand.

18300.text: ¶Behold Zion, the city of our festivals!/_Your eyes will see Jerusalem as a tranquil dwelling place,/_A tent that will not be moved./_Never will its tent pins be pulled out,/_And none of its ropes will be torn apart.

18301.text: ¶But there the Majestic One, Jehovah,/_Will be for us a region of rivers, of wide canals,/_Where no galley fleet will go/_And no majestic ships will pass by.

18302.text: ¶For Jehovah is our Judge,/_Jehovah is our Lawgiver,/_Jehovah is our King;/_He is the One who will save us.

18303.text: ¶Your ropes will hang loose;/_They cannot hold up the mast nor spread the sail./_At that time an abundance of spoil will be divided up;/_Even the lame will take much plunder.

18304.text: ¶And no resident will say: “I am sick.”/_The people dwelling in the land will be pardoned for their error.

18305.text: §¶Come close to hear, you nations,/_And pay attention, you peoples./_Let the earth and that which fills it listen,/_The land and all its produce.

18306.text: ¶ For Jehovah’s indignation is against all the nations,/_And his wrath is against all their army./_He will devote them to destruction;/_He will give them to the slaughter.

18307.text: ¶ Their slain will be thrown out,/_And the stench of their carcasses will ascend;/_The mountains will melt because of their blood.

18308.text: ¶ All the army of the heavens will rot away,/_And the heavens will be rolled up like a scroll./_All their army will wither away,/_As a withered leaf falls from the vine/_And a shriveled fig from the fig tree.

18309.text: ¶ “For in the heavens my sword will be drenched./_It will descend on Eʹdom in judgment,/_On the people whom I devoted to destruction.

18310.text: ¶ Jehovah has a sword; it will be covered with blood./_It will be covered with the fat,/_With the blood of young rams and goats,/_With the kidney fat of rams./_For Jehovah has a sacrifice in Bozʹrah,/_A great slaughter in the land of Eʹdom.

18311.text: ¶ The wild bulls will go down with them,/_The young bulls with the powerful ones./_Their land will be drenched in blood,/_And their dust will be soaked with fat.”

18312.text: ¶ For Jehovah has a day of vengeance,/_A year of retribution for the legal case over Zion.

18313.text: §¶ Her streams will be changed into pitch,/_And her dust into sulfur,/_And her land will become like burning pitch.

18314.text: ¶By night or by day it will not be extinguished;/_Its smoke will keep ascending forever./_From generation to generation she will remain devastated;/_No one will pass through her forever and ever.

18315.text: ¶The pelican and the porcupine will possess her,/_And long‑eared owls and ravens will reside in her./_He will stretch out over her the measuring line of emptiness/_And the plumb line of desolation.

18316.text: ¶None of her nobles will be called to the kingship,/_And all her princes will come to nothing.

18317.text: ¶Thorns will grow in her fortified towers,/_Nettles and thorny weeds in her fortresses./_She will become a lair of jackals,/_An enclosure for ostriches.

18318.text: ¶Desert creatures will meet up with howling animals,/_And the wild goat will call to its companion./_Yes, there the nightjar will settle and find a place of rest.

18319.text: ¶There the arrow snake will make its nest and lay eggs,/_And it will hatch them and gather them in its shadow./_Yes, there the kites will gather, each one with her mate.

18320.text: ¶Search in the book of Jehovah and read it out loud:/_Not one of them will be missing;/_None of them will be lacking a mate,/_For it is the mouth of Jehovah that has given the order,/_And it is his spirit that has gathered them together.

18321.text: ¶He is the One who has cast the lot for them,/_And his own hand has measured out their assigned place./_They will possess it for all time;/_They will reside in it throughout all generations.

18322.text: §¶The wilderness and the parched land will exult,/_And the desert plain will be joyful and blossom as the saffron.

18323.text: ¶ Without fail it will blossom;/_It will rejoice and shout for joy./_The glory of Lebʹa·non will be given to it,/_The splendor of Carʹmel and of Sharʹon./_They will see the glory of Jehovah, the splendor of our God.

18324.text: ¶ Strengthen the weak hands,/_And make firm the knees that are shaking.

18325.text: ¶ Say to those who are anxious at heart:/_“Be strong. Do not be afraid./_Look! Your own God will come with vengeance,/_God will come with retribution./_He will come and save you.”

18326.text: ¶ At that time the eyes of the blind will be opened,/_And the ears of the deaf will be unstopped.

18327.text: ¶ At that time the lame will leap like the deer,/_And the tongue of the speechless will shout for joy./_For waters will burst forth in the wilderness,/_And streams in the desert plain.

18328.text: ¶ The heat‑parched ground will become a reedy pool,/_And the thirsty ground springs of water./_In the lairs where jackals rested,/_There will be green grass and reeds and papyrus.

18329.text: §¶ And a highway will be there,/_Yes, a way called the Way of Holiness./_The unclean one will not travel on it./_It is reserved for the one walking on the way;/_No one foolish will stray onto it.

18330.text: ¶ No lion will be there,/_And no vicious wild beasts will come on it./_They will not be found there;/_Only the repurchased ones will walk there.

18331.text: ¶Those redeemed by Jehovah will return and come to Zion with a joyful cry./_Unending joy will crown their heads./_Exultation and rejoicing will be theirs,/_And grief and sighing will flee away.

18332.text: §¶In the 14th year of King Hez·e·kiʹah, Sen·nachʹer·ib the king of As·syrʹi·a came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

18333.text: The king of As·syrʹi·a then sent the Rabʹsha·keh with a vast army from Laʹchish to King Hez·e·kiʹah in Jerusalem. They took up a position by the conduit of the upper pool, which is at the highway of the laundryman’s field.

18334.text: Then E·liʹa·kim son of Hil·kiʹah, who was in charge of the household, Shebʹna the secretary, and Joʹah son of Aʹsaph the recorder came out to him.

18335.text: §¶So the Rabʹsha·keh said to them: “Please, say to Hez·e·kiʹah, ‘This is what the great king, the king of As·syrʹi·a, says: “What is the basis for your confidence?

18336.text: You are saying, ‘I have a strategy and the power to wage war,’ but these are empty words. In whom have you put trust, so that you dare to rebel against me?

18337.text: Look! You trust in the support of this crushed reed, Egypt, which if a man should lean on it would enter into his palm and pierce it. That is the way Pharʹaoh king of Egypt is to all those who trust in him.

18338.text: And if you should say to me, ‘We trust in Jehovah our God,’ is he not the one whose high places and altars Hez·e·kiʹah has removed, while he says to Judah and Jerusalem, ‘You should bow down before this altar’?”’

18339.text: So now make this wager, please, with my lord the king of As·syrʹi·a: I will give you 2,000 horses if you are able to find enough riders for them.

18340.text: How, then, could you drive back even one governor who is the least of my lord’s servants, while you put your trust in Egypt for chariots and for horsemen?

18341.text: Now is it without authorization from Jehovah that I have come up against this land to destroy it? Jehovah himself said to me, ‘Go up against this land and destroy it.’”

18342.text: ¶At this E·liʹa·kim and Shebʹna and Joʹah said to the Rabʹsha·keh: “Speak to your servants, please, in the Ar·a·maʹic language, for we can understand it; do not speak to us in the language of the Jews in the hearing of the people on the wall.”

18343.text: But the Rabʹsha·keh said: “Is it just to your lord and to you that my lord sent me to speak these words? Is it not also to the men who sit on the wall, those who will eat their own excrement and drink their own urine along with you?”

18344.text: ¶Then the Rabʹsha·keh stood and called out loudly in the language of the Jews, saying: “Hear the word of the great king, the king of As·syrʹi·a.

18345.text: This is what the king says, ‘Do not let Hez·e·kiʹah deceive you, for he is not able to rescue you.

18346.text: And do not let Hez·e·kiʹah cause you to trust in Jehovah by saying: “Jehovah will surely rescue us, and this city will not be given into the hand of the king of As·syrʹi·a.”

18347.text: Do not listen to Hez·e·kiʹah, for this is what the king of As·syrʹi·a says: “Make peace with me and surrender, and each of you will eat from his own vine and from his own fig tree and will drink the water of his own cistern,

18348.text: until I come and take you to a land like your own land, a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards.

18349.text: Do not let Hez·e·kiʹah mislead you by saying, ‘Jehovah will rescue us.’ Have any of the gods of the nations rescued their land out of the hand of the king of As·syrʹi·a?

18350.text: Where are the gods of Haʹmath and Arʹpad? Where are the gods of Seph·ar·vaʹim? And have they rescued Sa·marʹi·a out of my hand?

18351.text: Who among all the gods of these lands have rescued their land out of my hand, so that Jehovah should rescue Jerusalem out of my hand?”’”

18352.text: ¶But they kept silent and did not say a word to him in reply, for the order of the king was, “You must not answer him.”

18353.text: But E·liʹa·kim son of Hil·kiʹah, who was in charge of the household, Shebʹna the secretary, and Joʹah son of Aʹsaph the recorder came to Hez·e·kiʹah with their garments ripped apart and told him the words of the Rabʹsha·keh.

18354.text: §¶As soon as King Hez·e·kiʹah heard this, he ripped his garments apart and covered himself with sackcloth and went into the house of Jehovah.

18355.text: Then he sent E·liʹa·kim, who was in charge of the household, Shebʹna the secretary, and the elders of the priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah, the son of Aʹmoz.

18356.text: They said to him: “This is what Hez·e·kiʹah says, ‘This day is a day of distress, of rebuke, and of disgrace; for the children are ready to be born, but there is no strength to give birth.

18357.text: Perhaps Jehovah your God will hear the words of the Rabʹsha·keh, whom the king of As·syrʹi·a his lord sent to taunt the living God, and he will call him to account for the words that Jehovah your God has heard. So offer up a prayer in behalf of the remnant who have survived.’”

18358.text: ¶So the servants of King Hez·e·kiʹah went in to Isaiah,

18359.text: and Isaiah said to them: “This is what you should say to your lord, ‘This is what Jehovah says: “Do not be afraid because of the words that you heard, the words with which the attendants of the king of As·syrʹi·a blasphemed me.

18360.text: Here I am putting a thought in his mind, and he will hear a report and return to his own land; and I will make him fall by the sword in his own land.”’”

18361.text: §¶After the Rabʹsha·keh heard that the king of As·syrʹi·a had pulled away from Laʹchish, he returned to him and found him fighting against Libʹnah.

18362.text: Now the king heard it said about King Tir·haʹkah of E·thi·oʹpi·a: “He has come out to fight against you.” When he heard this, he sent messengers again to Hez·e·kiʹah, saying:

18363.text: “This is what you should say to King Hez·e·kiʹah of Judah, ‘Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you by saying: “Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of As·syrʹi·a.”

18364.text: Look! You have heard what the kings of As·syrʹi·a did to all the lands by devoting them to destruction. Will you alone be rescued?

18365.text: Did the gods of the nations that my forefathers destroyed rescue them? Where are Goʹzan, Haʹran, Reʹzeph, and the people of Eʹden who were in Tel‑asʹsar?

18366.text: Where is the king of Haʹmath, the king of Arʹpad, and the king of the cities of Seph·ar·vaʹim, and of Heʹna, and of Ivʹvah?’”

18367.text: §¶Hez·e·kiʹah took the letters out of the hand of the messengers and read them. Hez·e·kiʹah then went up to the house of Jehovah and spread them out before Jehovah.

18368.text: And Hez·e·kiʹah began to pray to Jehovah and say:

18369.text: “O Jehovah of armies, the God of Israel, sitting enthroned above the cherubs, you alone are the true God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You made the heavens and the earth.

18370.text: Incline your ear, O Jehovah, and hear! Open your eyes, O Jehovah, and see! Hear all the words that Sen·nachʹer·ib has sent to taunt the living God.

18371.text: It is a fact, O Jehovah, that the kings of As·syrʹi·a have devastated all the lands, as well as their own land.

18372.text: And they have thrown their gods into the fire, because they were not gods but the work of human hands, wood and stone. That is why they could destroy them.

18373.text: But now, O Jehovah our God, save us out of his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone are God, O Jehovah.”

18374.text: §¶Isaiah son of Aʹmoz then sent this message to Hez·e·kiʹah: “This is what Jehovah the God of Israel says, ‘Because you prayed to me concerning King Sen·nachʹer·ib of As·syrʹi·a,

18375.text: this is the word that Jehovah has spoken against him:¶▼“The virgin daughter of Zion despises you, she scoffs at you./_The daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head at you.

18376.text: ¶Whom have you taunted and blasphemed?/_Against whom have you raised your voice/_And lifted your arrogant eyes?/_It is against the Holy One of Israel!

18377.text: ¶Through your servants you have taunted Jehovah and said,/_‘With the multitude of my war chariots/_I will ascend the heights of mountains,/_The remotest parts of Lebʹa·non./_I will cut down its lofty cedars, its choice juniper trees./_I will enter its highest retreats, its densest forests.

18378.text: ¶I will dig wells and drink waters;/_I will dry up the streams of Egypt with the soles of my feet.’

18379.text: ¶Have you not heard? From long ago it was determined./_From days gone by I have prepared it./_Now I will bring it about./_You will turn fortified cities into desolate piles of ruins.

18380.text: ¶Their inhabitants will be helpless;/_They will be terrified and put to shame./_They will become as vegetation of the field and green grass,/_As grass of the roofs that is scorched by the east wind.

18381.text: ¶But I well know when you sit, when you go out, when you come in,/_And when you are enraged against me,

18382.text: ¶Because your rage against me and your roaring have reached my ears./_So I will put my hook in your nose and my bridle between your lips,/_And I will lead you back the way you came.”

18383.text: ¶“‘And this will be the sign for you: This year you will eat what grows on its own; and in the second year, you will eat grain that sprouts from that; but in the third year you will sow seed and reap, and you will plant vineyards and eat their fruitage.

18384.text: Those of the house of Judah who escape, those who are left, will take root downward and produce fruit upward.

18385.text: For a remnant will go out of Jerusalem and survivors from Mount Zion. The zeal of Jehovah of armies will do this.

18386.text: ¶“‘Therefore this is what Jehovah says about the king of As·syrʹi·a:¶▼“He will not come into this city/_Or shoot an arrow there/_Or confront it with a shield/_Or cast up a siege rampart against it.”’

18387.text: ¶‘By the way he came he will return;/_He will not come into this city,’ declares Jehovah.

18388.text: ¶‘I will defend this city and save it for my own sake/_And for the sake of my servant David.’”

18389.text: §¶And the angel of Jehovah went out and struck down 185,000 men in the camp of the As·syrʹi·ans. When people rose up early in the morning, they saw all the dead bodies.

18390.text: So King Sen·nachʹer·ib of As·syrʹi·a departed and returned to Ninʹe·veh and stayed there.

18391.text: And as he was bowing down at the house of his god Nisʹroch, his own sons A·dramʹme·lech and Shar·eʹzer struck him down with the sword and then escaped to the land of Arʹa·rat. And his son Eʹsar‑hadʹdon became king in his place.

18392.text: §¶In those days Hez·e·kiʹah became sick and was at the point of death. The prophet Isaiah the son of Aʹmoz came and said to him, “This is what Jehovah says: ‘Give instructions to your household, for you will die; you will not recover.’”

18393.text: At that Hez·e·kiʹah turned his face to the wall and began to pray to Jehovah:

18394.text: “I beg you, O Jehovah, remember, please, how I have walked before you faithfully and with a complete heart, and I have done what was good in your eyes.” And Hez·e·kiʹah began to weep profusely.

18395.text: ¶Then the word of Jehovah came to Isaiah, saying:

18396.text: “Go back and say to Hez·e·kiʹah, ‘This is what Jehovah the God of David your forefather says: “I have heard your prayer. I have seen your tears. Here I am adding 15 years to your life,

18397.text: and I will rescue you and this city out of the hand of the king of As·syrʹi·a, and I will defend this city.

18398.text: This is the sign from Jehovah to show you that Jehovah will carry out the word that he has spoken:

18399.text: Here I will make the declining shadow of the sun on the stairway of Aʹhaz go back ten steps.”’” So the sun went back ten steps on the stairway that it had already descended.

18400.text: ¶A writing of King Hez·e·kiʹah of Judah when he became sick and recovered from his sickness.

18401.text: ¶I said: “In the middle of my life/_I must go into the gates of the Grave./_I will be deprived of my remaining years.”

18402.text: ¶I said: “I will not see Jah, Jah in the land of the living./_I will look no more on mankind/_When I am with the inhabitants of the place where everything ceases.

18403.text: ¶My own dwelling has been pulled out and removed from me/_Like the tent of a shepherd./_I have rolled up my life like a loom worker;/_He cuts me off like the threads of the warp./_From daylight to nightfall you keep bringing me to an end.

18404.text: ¶I calm myself until the morning./_Like a lion, he keeps breaking all my bones;/_From daylight to nightfall you keep bringing me to an end.

18405.text: ¶Like the swift or the thrush, so I keep chirping;/_I keep cooing like the dove./_My eyes look wearily to the height:/_‘O Jehovah, I am in great distress;/_Be my support!’

18406.text: ¶What can I say?/_He has spoken to me and acted./_I will walk humbly all my years/_Because of my bitter distress.

18407.text: ¶‘O Jehovah, by these things every man lives,/_And in them is the life of my spirit./_You will restore me to health and preserve me alive.

18408.text: ¶Look! Instead of peace, I had great bitterness;/_But in your fondness for me,/_You preserved me from the pit of destruction./_You have thrown all my sins behind your back.

18409.text: ¶For the Grave cannot glorify you,/_Death cannot praise you./_Those who go down into the pit cannot hope for your faithfulness.

18410.text: ¶The living, the living can praise you,/_Just as I can this day./_A father can give his sons knowledge about your faithfulness.

18411.text: ¶O Jehovah, save me,/_And we will play my songs on stringed instruments/_All the days of our life at the house of Jehovah.’”

18412.text: ¶Isaiah then said: “Bring a cake of pressed dried figs and apply it to the boil, so that he may recover.”

18413.text: Hez·e·kiʹah had asked: “What is the sign that I will go up to the house of Jehovah?”

18414.text: §¶At that time the king of Babylon, Merʹo·dach‑balʹa·dan son of Balʹa·dan, sent letters and a gift to Hez·e·kiʹah, for he had heard that he had been sick and had recovered.

18415.text: Hez·e·kiʹah gladly welcomed them and showed them his treasure‑house—the silver, the gold, the balsam oil and other precious oil, his whole armory, and everything that was to be found in his treasuries. There was nothing that Hez·e·kiʹah did not show them in his own house and in all his dominion.

18416.text: ¶After that Isaiah the prophet came in to King Hez·e·kiʹah and asked him: “What did these men say, and where did they come from?” So Hez·e·kiʹah said: “They came from a distant land, from Babylon.”

18417.text: Next he asked: “What did they see in your house?” Hez·e·kiʹah replied: “They saw everything in my house. There was nothing that I did not show them in my treasuries.”

18418.text: ¶Isaiah now said to Hez·e·kiʹah: “Hear the word of Jehovah of armies,

18419.text: ‘Look! Days are coming, and all that is in your house and all that your forefathers have stored up to this day will be carried off to Babylon. Nothing will be left,’ says Jehovah.

18420.text: ‘And some of your own sons to whom you will become father will be taken and will become court officials in the palace of the king of Babylon.’”

18421.text: ¶At that Hez·e·kiʹah said to Isaiah: “The word of Jehovah that you have spoken is good.” Then he added: “Because there will be peace and stability during my lifetime.”

18422.text: §¶“Comfort, comfort my people,” says your God.

18423.text: ¶ “Speak to the heart of Jerusalem,/_And proclaim to her that her compulsory service has been fulfilled,/_That her guilt has been paid off./_From the hand of Jehovah she has received a full amount for all her sins.”

18424.text: ¶ A voice of one calling out in the wilderness:/_“Clear up the way of Jehovah!/_Make a straight highway through the desert for our God.

18425.text: ¶ Let every valley be raised up,/_And every mountain and hill be made low./_The rough ground must become level,/_And the rugged ground a valley plain.

18426.text: ¶ The glory of Jehovah will be revealed,/_And all flesh will see it together,/_For the mouth of Jehovah has spoken.”

18427.text: ¶ Listen! Someone is saying: “Call out!”/_Another asks: “What should I call out?”/_“All flesh is green grass./_All their loyal love is like the blossom of the field.

18428.text: ¶ The green grass dries up,/_The blossom withers,/_Because the breath of Jehovah blows upon it./_Surely the people are but green grass.

18429.text: ¶ The green grass dries up,/_The blossom withers,/_But the word of our God endures forever.”

18430.text: ¶ Go up onto a high mountain,/_You woman bringing good news for Zion./_Raise your voice with power,/_You woman bringing good news for Jerusalem./_Raise it, do not be afraid./_Announce to the cities of Judah: “Here is your God.”

18431.text: ¶Look! The Sovereign Lord Jehovah will come with power,/_And his arm will rule for him./_Look! His reward is with him,/_And the wage he pays is before him.

18432.text: ¶Like a shepherd he will care for his flock./_With his arm he will gather together the lambs,/_And in his bosom he will carry them./_He will gently lead those nursing their young.

18433.text: §¶Who has measured the waters in the hollow of his hand/_And taken the measurements of the heavens with a span of his hand?/_Who has gathered in a measure the dust of the earth/_Or weighed the mountains in the balances/_And the hills in the scales?

18434.text: ¶Who has taken the measurements of the spirit of Jehovah,/_And who can instruct him as his adviser?

18435.text: ¶With whom did he consult to gain understanding,/_Or who teaches him in the path of justice,/_Or teaches him knowledge,/_Or shows him the way of true understanding?

18436.text: ¶Look! The nations are like a drop from a bucket,/_And as the film of dust on the scales they are regarded./_Look! He lifts up the islands like fine dust.

18437.text: ¶Even Lebʹa·non is not sufficient to keep a fire burning,/_And its wild animals are not sufficient for a burnt offering.

18438.text: ¶All the nations are as something nonexistent in front of him;/_He regards them as nothing, as an unreality.

18439.text: ¶To whom can you compare God?/_What likeness can you put next to him?

18440.text: ¶The craftsman casts an idol,/_The metalworker overlays it with gold,/_And he forges silver chains.

18441.text: ¶He chooses a tree for his contribution,/_A tree that will not rot./_He searches for a skilled craftsman/_To prepare a carved image that will not topple over.

18442.text: ¶Do you not know?/_Have you not heard?/_Has it not been told to you from the beginning?/_Have you not understood from the foundations of the earth?

18443.text: ¶There is One who dwells above the circle of the earth,/_And its inhabitants are like grasshoppers./_He is stretching out the heavens like a fine gauze,/_And he spreads them out like a tent to dwell in.

18444.text: ¶He reduces high officials to nothing/_And makes the judges of the earth an unreality.

18445.text: ¶They are hardly planted,/_They are hardly sown,/_Their stem has hardly taken root in the earth,/_And they are blown on and dry up,/_And the wind carries them away like stubble.

18446.text: ¶“To whom can you liken me to make me his equal?” says the Holy One.

18447.text: ¶“Lift up your eyes to heaven and see./_Who has created these things?/_It is the One who brings out their army by number;/_He calls them all by name./_Because of his vast dynamic energy and his awe‑inspiring power,/_Not one of them is missing.

18448.text: ¶Why do you say, O Jacob, and why do you declare, O Israel,/_‘My way is hidden from Jehovah,/_And I receive no justice from God’?

18449.text: ¶Do you not know? Have you not heard?/_Jehovah, the Creator of the ends of the earth, is a God for all eternity./_He never tires out or grows weary./_His understanding is unsearchable.

18450.text: ¶He gives power to the tired one/_And full might to those lacking strength.

18451.text: ¶Boys will tire out and grow weary,/_And young men will stumble and fall,

18452.text: ¶But those hoping in Jehovah will regain power./_They will soar on wings like eagles./_They will run and not grow weary;/_They will walk and not tire out.”

18453.text: §¶“Listen to me in silence, you islands;/_Let the nations regain their strength./_Let them approach; then let them speak./_Let us come together for judgment.

18454.text: ¶ Who has raised up someone from the sunrise,/_Calling him in righteousness to His feet,/_To hand over nations to him/_And to make him subdue kings?/_Who reduces them to dust before his sword,/_Like windblown stubble before his bow?

18455.text: ¶ He pursues them, passing along unhindered/_Over paths that his feet have not traveled.

18456.text: ¶ Who has acted and done this,/_Summoning the generations from the beginning?/_I, Jehovah, am the First One;/_And with the last ones I am the same.”

18457.text: ¶ The islands have seen it and have become afraid./_The ends of the earth began to tremble./_They draw near and come forward.

18458.text: ¶ Each one helps his companion/_And says to his brother: “Be strong.”

18459.text: ¶ So the craftsman strengthens the metalworker;/_The one who flattens with the forge hammer/_Strengthens the one hammering at the anvil./_He says about the soldering: “It is good.”/_Then it is fastened with nails so that it will not topple over.

18460.text: §¶ “But you, O Israel, are my servant,/_You, O Jacob, whom I have chosen,/_The offspring of Abraham my friend,

18461.text: ¶ You, whom I took from the ends of the earth,/_And you, whom I called from its most distant parts./_I said to you, ‘You are my servant;/_I have chosen you; I have not rejected you.

18462.text: ¶Do not be afraid, for I am with you./_Do not be anxious, for I am your God./_I will fortify you, yes, I will help you,/_I will really hold on to you with my right hand of righteousness.’

18463.text: ¶Look! All those getting enraged against you will be put to shame and humiliated./_Those who fight with you will be brought to nothing and perish.

18464.text: ¶You will search for men who struggle with you, but you will not find them;/_The men at war with you will become as something nonexistent, as nothing at all.

18465.text: ¶For I, Jehovah your God, am grasping your right hand,/_The One saying to you, ‘Do not be afraid. I will help you.’

18466.text: ¶Do not be afraid, you worm Jacob,/_You men of Israel, I will help you,” declares Jehovah, your Repurchaser, the Holy One of Israel.

18467.text: ¶“Look! I have made you a threshing sledge,/_A new threshing instrument with double‑edged teeth./_You will tread down the mountains and crush them/_And make the hills like chaff.

18468.text: ¶You will winnow them,/_And the wind will carry them away;/_A windstorm will scatter them./_You will be joyful in Jehovah,/_And you will boast in the Holy One of Israel.”

18469.text: ¶“The needy and the poor are seeking water, but there is none./_Their tongue is dry from thirst./_I, Jehovah, will answer them./_I, the God of Israel, will not abandon them.

18470.text: ¶I will make rivers flow on the bare hills/_And springs in the valley plains./_I will turn the wilderness into a reedy pool of water/_And the waterless land into springs of water.

18471.text: ¶In the desert I will plant the cedar tree,/_The acacia and the myrtle and the pine tree./_In the desert plain I will plant the juniper tree,/_Together with the ash and the cypress tree,

18472.text: ¶So that all people may see and know/_And pay attention and understand/_That the hand of Jehovah has done this,/_And the Holy One of Israel has created it.”

18473.text: §¶“Present your case,” says Jehovah./_“Produce your arguments,” says the King of Jacob.

18474.text: ¶“Produce evidence and tell us the things that will happen./_Do tell us about the former things,/_So that we may reflect on them and know their outcome./_Or declare to us the things that are coming.

18475.text: ¶Tell us what will happen in the future,/_So that we may know that you are gods./_Yes, do something, good or bad,/_So that we may be amazed when we see it.

18476.text: ¶Look! You are something nonexistent,/_And your achievement is nothing./_Anyone who chooses you is detestable.

18477.text: ¶I have raised up someone from the north, and he will come,/_One from the rising of the sun who will call on my name./_He will trample rulers as if they were clay,/_Like a potter who treads moist clay.

18478.text: ¶Who told about this from the beginning, so that we could know,/_Or from times past, so that we could say, ‘He is right’?/_Indeed, no one announced it!/_No one declared it!/_No one heard anything from you!”

18479.text: ¶I was the first to say to Zion: “Look! Here they are!”/_And to Jerusalem I will send a bearer of good news.

18480.text: ¶But I kept looking, and there was no one;/_There was not one among them to give advice./_And I kept asking them to reply.

18481.text: ¶Look! All of them are a delusion./_Their works are nothing./_Their metal images are wind and unreality.

18482.text: §¶Look! My servant, whom I support!/_My chosen one, whom I have approved!/_I have put my spirit in him;/_He will bring justice to the nations.

18483.text: ¶ He will not cry out or raise his voice,/_And he will not make his voice heard in the street.

18484.text: ¶ No crushed reed will he break,/_And no smoldering wick will he extinguish./_In faithfulness he will bring justice.

18485.text: ¶ He will not grow dim or be crushed until he establishes justice in the earth;/_And the islands keep waiting for his law.

18486.text: ¶ This is what the true God, Jehovah, says,/_The Creator of the heavens and the Grand One who stretched them out,/_The One who spread out the earth and its produce,/_The One who gives breath to the people on it/_And spirit to those who walk on it:

18487.text: ¶ “I, Jehovah, have called you in righteousness;/_I have taken hold of your hand./_I will safeguard you and give you as a covenant for the people/_And as a light of the nations,

18488.text: ¶ For you to open the blind eyes,/_To bring the prisoner out of the dungeon/_And those sitting in darkness out of the prison.

18489.text: ¶ I am Jehovah. That is my name;/_I give my glory to no one else,/_Nor my praise to graven images.

18490.text: ¶ See, the first things have come to pass;/_Now I am declaring new things./_Before they spring up, I tell you about them.”

18491.text: §¶Sing to Jehovah a new song,/_His praise from the ends of the earth,/_You who go down to the sea and all that fills it,/_You islands and their inhabitants.

18492.text: ¶Let the wilderness and its cities raise their voice,/_The settlements where Keʹdar dwells./_Let the inhabitants of the crag shout joyfully;/_Let them cry out from the top of the mountains.

18493.text: ¶Let them attribute glory to Jehovah/_And declare his praise in the islands.

18494.text: ¶Jehovah will go out like a mighty man./_He will awaken his zeal like a warrior./_He will shout, yes, he will let out a war cry;/_He will show himself mightier than his enemies.

18495.text: ¶“I have kept quiet for a long time./_I remained silent and restrained myself./_Like a woman giving birth,/_I will groan, pant, and gasp all at once.

18496.text: ¶I will devastate mountains and hills/_And dry up all their vegetation./_I will turn rivers into islands/_And dry up reedy pools of water.

18497.text: ¶I will lead the blind in a way that they do not know/_And cause them to tread on unfamiliar paths./_I will turn the darkness before them into light/_And turn the rugged terrain into level land./_This is what I will do for them, and I will not abandon them.”

18498.text: ¶They will be turned back and will be utterly put to shame,/_Those who trust in carved images,/_Those who say to metal statues: “You are our gods.”

18499.text: §¶Listen, you who are deaf;/_Look and see, you who are blind.

18500.text: ¶Who is blind except my servant,/_So deaf as the messenger I send?/_Who is so blind as the one rewarded,/_So blind as the servant of Jehovah?

18501.text: ¶You see many things, but you do not keep watch./_You open your ears, but you do not listen.

18502.text: ¶For the sake of his righteousness,/_Jehovah has taken pleasure in magnifying the law and making it glorious.

18503.text: ¶But this is a people plundered and pillaged;/_All of them are trapped in the holes and hidden in the prisons./_They have been plundered with no one to rescue them,/_And pillaged with no one to say: “Bring them back!”

18504.text: ¶Who among you will hear this?/_Who will pay attention and listen for the time to come?

18505.text: ¶Who has given Jacob for pillage/_And Israel to the plunderers?/_Is it not Jehovah, the One against whom we sinned?/_In His ways they refused to walk,/_And His law they would not obey.

18506.text: ¶So He kept pouring out on him wrath,/_His anger and the fury of war./_It consumed everything around him, but he paid no attention./_It blazed up against him, but he would not take it to heart.

18507.text: §¶Now this is what Jehovah says,/_Your Creator, O Jacob, the One who formed you, O Israel:/_“Do not be afraid, for I have repurchased you./_I have called you by your name./_You belong to me.

18508.text: ¶ When you pass through the waters, I will be with you,/_And through the rivers, they will not flood over you./_When you walk through the fire, you will not be scorched,/_Nor will the flame singe you.

18509.text: ¶ For I am Jehovah your God,/_The Holy One of Israel, your Savior./_I have given Egypt as a ransom for you,/_E·thi·oʹpi·a and Seʹba in exchange for you.

18510.text: ¶ For you became precious in my eyes,/_You were honored, and I have loved you./_So I will give people in place of you/_And nations in exchange for your life.

18511.text: ¶ Do not be afraid, for I am with you./_I will bring your offspring from the east/_And gather you together from the west.

18512.text: ¶ I will say to the north, ‘Give them up!’/_And to the south, ‘Do not hold them back./_Bring my sons from afar, and my daughters from the ends of the earth,

18513.text: ¶ Everyone who is called by my name/_And whom I created for my own glory,/_Whom I have formed and made.’

18514.text: §¶ Bring out a people who are blind, though they have eyes,/_And who are deaf, though they have ears.

18515.text: ¶ Let all the nations assemble in one place,/_And let the peoples be gathered together./_Who among them can tell this?/_Or can they cause us to hear the first things?/_Let them present their witnesses to prove themselves right,/_Or let them hear and say, ‘It is the truth!’”

18516.text: ¶“You are my witnesses,” declares Jehovah,/_“Yes, my servant whom I have chosen,/_So that you may know and have faith in me/_And understand that I am the same One./_Before me no God was formed,/_And after me there has been none.

18517.text: ¶I—I am Jehovah, and besides me there is no savior.”

18518.text: ¶“I am the One who declared and saved and made known/_When there was no foreign god among you./_So you are my witnesses,” declares Jehovah, “and I am God.

18519.text: ¶Also, I am always the same One;/_And no one can snatch anything out of my hand./_When I act, who can prevent it?”

18520.text: §¶This is what Jehovah says, your Repurchaser, the Holy One of Israel:/_“For your sakes I will send to Babylon and bring down all the bars of the gates,/_And the Chal·deʹans, in their ships, will cry out in distress.

18521.text: ¶I am Jehovah, your Holy One, the Creator of Israel, your King.”

18522.text: ¶This is what Jehovah says,/_The One making a way through the sea/_And a path even through turbulent waters,

18523.text: ¶The One who draws out the war chariot and the horse,/_The army together with the mighty warriors:/_“They will lie down and not get up./_They will be extinguished, snuffed out like a burning wick.”

18524.text: ¶“Do not remember the former things,/_And do not dwell on the past.

18525.text: ¶Look! I am doing something new;/_Even now it is springing up./_Do you not recognize it?/_I will make a way through the wilderness/_And rivers through the desert.

18526.text: ¶The wild beast of the field will honor me,/_The jackals and the ostriches,/_For I provide water in the wilderness,/_Rivers in the desert,/_For my people, my chosen one, to drink,

18527.text: ¶The people whom I formed for myself/_So that they might declare my praise.

18528.text: §¶But you have not called on me, O Jacob,/_Because you grew weary of me, O Israel.

18529.text: ¶You have not brought me sheep for your whole burnt offerings/_Or glorified me with your sacrifices./_I have not compelled you to bring me a gift,/_Nor have I made you weary by demanding frankincense.

18530.text: ¶You did not buy me sweet cane with your money,/_And with the fat of your sacrifices you did not satisfy me./_Instead, you have burdened me with your sins/_And made me weary with your errors.

18531.text: ¶I, I am the One who is blotting out your transgressions for my own sake,/_And I will not remember your sins.

18532.text: ¶Remind me; let us bring our case against each other;/_Tell your side of it to prove you are in the right.

18533.text: ¶Your first forefather sinned,/_And your own spokesmen have rebelled against me.

18534.text: ¶So I will profane the princes of the holy place,/_And I will give Jacob over to destruction/_And subject Israel to insulting words.

18535.text: §¶“Now listen, O Jacob my servant,/_And you, O Israel, whom I have chosen.

18536.text: ¶ This is what Jehovah says,/_Your Maker and the One who formed you,/_Who has helped you from the womb:/_‘Do not be afraid, my servant Jacob,/_And you, Jeshʹu·run, whom I have chosen.

18537.text: ¶ For I will pour out water on the thirsty one/_And flowing streams on the dry ground./_I will pour out my spirit on your offspring/_And my blessing on your descendants.

18538.text: ¶ And they will spring up as among the green grass,/_Like poplars by the streams of water.

18539.text: ¶ One will say: “I belong to Jehovah.”/_Another will call himself by the name of Jacob,/_And yet another will write on his hand: “Belonging to Jehovah.”/_And he will adopt the name of Israel.’

18540.text: §¶ This is what Jehovah says,/_The King of Israel and his Repurchaser, Jehovah of armies:/_‘I am the first and I am the last./_There is no God but me.

18541.text: ¶ Who is there like me?/_Let him call out and tell it and prove it to me!/_From the time I established the people of long ago,/_Let them tell both the things to come/_And what will yet happen.

18542.text: ¶ Do not be in dread,/_And do not become paralyzed with fear./_Have I not told each of you beforehand and declared it?/_You are my witnesses./_Is there any God but me?/_No, there is no other Rock; I know of none.’”

18543.text: §¶ All who form carved images amount to nothing,/_And their cherished objects will be of no benefit./_As their witnesses, they see nothing and know nothing,/_So those who made them will be put to shame.

18544.text: ¶Who would form a god or cast a metal image/_That can bring no benefit?

18545.text: ¶Look! All his associates will be put to shame!/_The craftsmen are mere humans./_Let them all assemble and take their stand./_They will be terrified and be put to shame together.

18546.text: ¶The metalsmith works the iron over the coals with his tool./_He forms it with hammers,/_Working it with his powerful arm./_Then he grows hungry and his strength fails;/_He drinks no water and grows tired.

18547.text: ¶The wood‑carver stretches the measuring line, tracing out the pattern with red chalk./_He works it with a wood scraper and traces it with a compass./_He patterns it after a man,/_With the beauty of a man,/_To sit in a house.

18548.text: ¶There is one whose work is to cut down cedars./_He selects a certain type of tree, an oak,/_And he lets it grow strong among the trees of the forest./_He plants a laurel tree, and the rain makes it grow.

18549.text: ¶Then it becomes fuel for a man to make fires./_He takes part of it to warm himself;/_He builds a fire and bakes bread./_But he also makes a god and worships it./_He makes it into a carved image, and he bows down before it.

18550.text: ¶Half of it he burns up in a fire;/_With that half he roasts the meat that he eats, and he is satisfied./_He also warms himself and says:/_“Ah! I am warm as I watch the fire.”

18551.text: ¶But the rest of it he makes into a god, into his carved image./_He bows down to it and worships it./_He prays to it and says:/_“Save me, for you are my god.”

18552.text: ¶They know nothing, they understand nothing,/_Because their eyes are sealed shut and they cannot see,/_And their heart has no insight.

18553.text: ¶No one reflects in his heart/_Or has knowledge or understanding, saying:/_“Half of it I burned up in a fire,/_And on its coals I baked bread and roasted meat to eat./_Should I, then, make the rest of it into a detestable thing?/_Should I worship a block of wood from a tree?”

18554.text: ¶He feeds on ashes./_His own deluded heart has led him astray./_He cannot save himself, nor does he say:/_“Is there not a lie in my right hand?”

18555.text: §¶“Remember these things, O Jacob, and you, O Israel,/_For you are my servant./_I formed you, and you are my servant./_O Israel, I will not forget you.

18556.text: ¶I will blot out your transgressions as with a cloud/_And your sins as with a thick cloud./_Return to me, for I will repurchase you.

18557.text: ¶Shout joyfully, you heavens,/_For Jehovah has acted!/_Shout in triumph, you depths of the earth!/_Shout for joy, you mountains,/_You forest, and all your trees!/_For Jehovah has repurchased Jacob,/_And on Israel he displays his splendor.”

18558.text: §¶This is what Jehovah says, your Repurchaser,/_Who formed you since you were in the womb:/_“I am Jehovah, who made everything./_I stretched out the heavens by myself,/_And I spread out the earth./_Who was with me?

18559.text: ¶I am frustrating the signs of the empty talkers,/_And I am the One who makes diviners act like fools;/_The One confounding the wise men/_And turning their knowledge into foolishness;

18560.text: ¶The One making the word of his servant come true/_And completely fulfilling the predictions of his messengers;/_The One saying of Jerusalem, ‘She will be inhabited,’/_And of the cities of Judah, ‘They will be rebuilt,/_And I will restore her ruins’;

18561.text: ¶The One saying to the deep waters, ‘Be evaporated,/_And I will dry up all your rivers’;

18562.text: ¶The One saying of Cyrus, ‘He is my shepherd,/_And he will completely carry out all my will’;/_The One saying of Jerusalem, ‘She will be rebuilt,’/_And of the temple, ‘Your foundation will be laid.’”

18563.text: §¶This is what Jehovah says to his anointed one, to Cyrus,/_Whose right hand I have taken hold of/_To subdue nations before him,/_To disarm kings,/_To open before him the double doors,/_So that the gates will not be shut:

18564.text: ¶ “Before you I will go,/_And the hills I will level./_The copper doors I will break in pieces,/_And the iron bars I will cut down.

18565.text: ¶ I will give you the treasures in the darkness/_And the hidden treasures in the concealed places,/_So that you may know that I am Jehovah,/_The God of Israel, who is calling you by your name.

18566.text: ¶ For the sake of my servant Jacob and of Israel my chosen one,/_I am calling you by your name./_I am giving you a name of honor, although you did not know me.

18567.text: ¶ I am Jehovah, and there is no one else./_There is no God except me./_I will strengthen you, although you did not know me,

18568.text: ¶ In order that people may know/_From the rising of the sun to its setting/_That there is none besides me./_I am Jehovah, and there is no one else.

18569.text: ¶ I form light and create darkness,/_I make peace and create calamity;/_I, Jehovah, am doing all these things.

18570.text: ¶ You heavens, rain down from above;/_Let the clouds pour down righteousness./_Let the earth open up and be fruitful with salvation,/_And let it cause righteousness to spring up at the same time./_I, Jehovah, have created it.”

18571.text: §¶ Woe to the one who contends with his Maker,/_For he is just an earthenware fragment/_Among the other earthenware fragments lying on the ground!/_Should the clay say to the Potter: “What are you making?”/_Or should your work say: “He has no hands”?

18572.text: ¶Woe to the one who says to a father: “What do you become father to?”/_And to a woman: “What are you giving birth to?”

18573.text: ¶This is what Jehovah says, the Holy One of Israel, the One who formed him:/_“Would you question me about the things coming/_And command me about my sons and the works of my hands?

18574.text: ¶I made the earth and created man on it./_I stretched out the heavens with my own hands,/_And I give orders to all their army.”

18575.text: ¶“I have raised up a man in righteousness,/_And I will make all his ways straight./_He is the one who will build my city/_And set my exiles free without a price or a bribe,” says Jehovah of armies.

18576.text: §¶This is what Jehovah says:/_“The profit of Egypt and the merchandise of E·thi·oʹpi·a and the Sa·beʹans, tall of stature,/_Will come over to you and become yours./_They will walk behind you in chains./_They will come over and bow down to you./_To you they will say in prayer, ‘Surely God is with you,/_And there is no one else; there is no other God.’”

18577.text: ¶Truly you are a God who conceals himself,/_O God of Israel, the Savior.

18578.text: ¶They will all be put to shame and be humiliated;/_The makers of idols will all go off in disgrace.

18579.text: ¶But Israel will be saved by Jehovah with an everlasting salvation./_You will not be put to shame or disgraced for all eternity.

18580.text: §¶For this is what Jehovah says,/_The Creator of the heavens, the true God,/_The One who formed the earth, its Maker who firmly established it,/_Who did not create it simply for nothing, but formed it to be inhabited:/_“I am Jehovah, and there is no one else.

18581.text: ¶I did not speak in a concealed place, in a land of darkness;/_I did not say to the offspring of Jacob,/_‘Seek me simply for nothing.’/_I am Jehovah, who speaks what is righteous and declares what is upright.

18582.text: ¶Gather together and come./_Approach together, you escapees from the nations./_They know nothing, those who carry around carved images/_And pray to a god that cannot save them.

18583.text: ¶Make your report, present your case./_Let them consult together in unity./_Who foretold this long ago/_And declared it from times past?/_Is it not I, Jehovah?/_There is no other God but me;/_A righteous God and a Savior, there is none besides me.

18584.text: ¶Turn to me and be saved, all the ends of the earth,/_For I am God, and there is no one else.

18585.text: ¶By myself I have sworn;/_The word has gone out of my mouth in righteousness,/_And it will not return:/_To me every knee will bend,/_Every tongue will swear loyalty

18586.text: ¶And say, ‘Surely in Jehovah are true righteousness and strength./_All those enraged against him will come before him in shame.

18587.text: ¶In Jehovah all the offspring of Israel will prove to be right,/_And in him they will make their boast.’”

18588.text: §¶Bel bends down, Neʹbo stoops over./_Their idols are loaded on animals, on beasts of burden,/_Like baggage that burdens the weary animals.

18589.text: ¶ They stoop and bend down together;/_They cannot rescue the loads,/_And they themselves go into captivity.

18590.text: ¶ “Listen to me, O house of Jacob, and all you who remain of the house of Israel,/_You whom I have supported from birth and carried from the womb.

18591.text: ¶ Until you grow old I will be the same;/_Until your hair is gray I will keep bearing you./_As I have done, I will carry you and bear you and rescue you.

18592.text: ¶ To whom will you liken me or make me equal or compare me,/_So that we should resemble each other?

18593.text: ¶ There are those who lavish gold from their purse;/_They weigh out the silver on the scale./_They hire a metalworker, and he makes it into a god./_Then they prostrate themselves, yes, they worship it.

18594.text: ¶ They lift it to their shoulders;/_They carry it and put it in its place, and it just stands there./_It does not move from its place./_They cry out to it, but it does not answer;/_It cannot rescue anyone from distress.

18595.text: ¶ Remember this, and take courage./_Take it to heart, you transgressors.

18596.text: ¶ Remember the former things of long ago,/_That I am God, and there is no other./_I am God, and there is no one like me.

18597.text: ¶From the beginning I foretell the outcome,/_And from long ago the things that have not yet been done./_I say, ‘My decision will stand,/_And I will do whatever I please.’

18598.text: ¶I am calling a bird of prey from the sunrise,/_From a distant land the man to carry out my decision./_I have spoken, and I will bring it about./_I have purposed it, and I will also carry it out.

18599.text: ¶Listen to me, you who are stubborn of heart,/_You who are far away from righteousness.

18600.text: ¶I have brought my righteousness near;/_It is not far away,/_And my salvation will not delay./_I will grant salvation in Zion, my splendor to Israel.”

18601.text: §¶Come down and sit in the dust,/_O virgin daughter of Babylon./_Sit down on the ground where there is no throne,/_O daughter of the Chal·deʹans,/_For never again will people call you delicate and pampered.

18602.text: ¶ Take a hand mill and grind flour./_Remove your veil./_Strip off your skirt, uncover your legs./_Cross over the rivers.

18603.text: ¶ Your nakedness will be uncovered./_Your shame will be exposed./_I will take vengeance, and no man will stand in my way.

18604.text: ¶ “The One repurchasing us/_—Jehovah of armies is his name—/_Is the Holy One of Israel.”

18605.text: ¶ Sit there silently and go into darkness,/_O daughter of the Chal·deʹans;/_No more will they call you Mistress of Kingdoms.

18606.text: ¶ I grew indignant at my people./_I profaned my inheritance,/_And I gave them into your hand./_But you showed them no mercy./_Even on the elderly you placed a heavy yoke.

18607.text: ¶ You said: “I will always be the Mistress, forever.”/_You did not take these things to heart;/_You did not consider how the matter would end.

18608.text: ¶ Now hear this, O lover of pleasure,/_Who sits in security, who says in her heart:/_“I am the one, and there is no one else./_I will not become a widow./_I will never know the loss of children.”

18609.text: ¶ But these two things will come upon you suddenly, in one day:/_Loss of children and widowhood./_In full measure they will come upon you/_Because of your many sorceries and all your powerful spells.

18610.text: ¶You trusted in your wickedness./_You said: “No one sees me.”/_Your wisdom and knowledge are what led you astray,/_And you say in your heart: “I am the one, and there is no one else.”

18611.text: ¶But calamity will come upon you,/_And none of your charms will stop it./_Adversity will befall you; you will not be able to avert it./_Sudden ruin will come upon you like you have never known.

18612.text: ¶Go ahead, then, with your spells and your many sorceries,/_With which you have toiled from your youth./_Perhaps you may be able to benefit;/_Perhaps you may strike people with awe.

18613.text: ¶You have grown weary with the multitude of your advisers./_Let them stand up now and save you,/_Those who worship the heavens, who gaze at the stars,/_Those giving out knowledge at the new moons/_About the things that will come upon you.

18614.text: ¶Look! They are like stubble./_A fire will burn them up./_They cannot save themselves from the power of the flame./_These are not charcoals for keeping warm,/_And this is not a fire to sit in front of.

18615.text: ¶So your charmers will become to you,/_Those with whom you toiled from your youth./_They will wander, each one in his own direction./_There will be no one to save you.

18616.text: §¶Hear this, O house of Jacob,/_You who call yourselves by the name of Israel/_And who have come from the waters of Judah,/_You who swear by the name of Jehovah/_And who call on the God of Israel,/_Though not in truth and righteousness.

18617.text: ¶ For they call themselves after the holy city/_And seek the support of the God of Israel,/_Whose name is Jehovah of armies.

18618.text: ¶ “The former things I told you long ago./_From my own mouth they went out,/_And I made them known./_Suddenly I took action, and they came about.

18619.text: ¶ Because I knew how stubborn you are/_—That your neck is an iron sinew and your forehead is copper—

18620.text: ¶ I told you long ago./_Before it came about, I caused you to hear it,/_So that you could not say, ‘My idol did this;/_My carved image and my metal image commanded this.’

18621.text: ¶ You have heard and seen all of this./_Will you not declare it?/_From now on I am announcing new things to you,/_Guarded secrets that you have not known.

18622.text: ¶ Only now are they being created, and not long ago,/_Things that you never heard before today,/_So that you cannot say, ‘Look! I already know them.’

18623.text: ¶ No, you have not heard, you have not known,/_And in the past your ears were not opened./_For I know that you are very treacherous,/_And you have been called a transgressor from birth.

18624.text: ¶ But for the sake of my name I will hold back my anger;/_For my own praise I will restrain myself toward you,/_And I will not do away with you.

18625.text: ¶Look! I have refined you, but not in the form of silver./_I have tested you in the smelting furnace of affliction.

18626.text: ¶For my own sake, for my own sake I will act,/_For how could I let myself be profaned?/_I give my glory to no one else.

18627.text: §¶Listen to me, O Jacob, and Israel, whom I have called./_I am the same One. I am the first; I am also the last.

18628.text: ¶My own hand laid the foundation of the earth,/_And my right hand spread out the heavens./_When I call to them, they stand up together.

18629.text: ¶Gather together, all of you, and listen./_Who among them has announced these things?/_Jehovah has loved him./_He will carry out his delight against Babylon,/_And his arm will come against the Chal·deʹans.

18630.text: ¶I myself have spoken, and I have called him./_I have brought him, and his way will be successful.

18631.text: §¶Come near to me, and hear this./_From the very start I have not spoken in secret./_From the time it happened I was there.”/_And now the Sovereign Lord Jehovah has sent me, and his spirit.

18632.text: ¶This is what Jehovah says, your Repurchaser, the Holy One of Israel:/_“I, Jehovah, am your God,/_The One teaching you to benefit yourself,/_The One guiding you in the way you should walk.
